folklore: Other members of the Pinaceae or pine family can be set apart from Abies by how the needles look flat and how they attach to the twig.
The needles of young Abies are sharper.
Abutilon are most usually orange or yellow, although they can be pink or red.
Legend tells that the Acacia tree could have been the “burning bush” that Moses encountered in Exodus 3:2 of the Holy Bible.
A sprig of Acacia senegal over a bed on a hat will supposedly ward off evil.
Acacia senegal will purify an area of evil and negativity.

Acanthus mollis leaves are reasonably believed to be the artistic inspiration for the elaborate leafy carvings used on the capitals of Corinthian columns that are liberally present in Greco-Roman architecture.
The seedpods of the Acer tree are unusual in that they occur connected in pairs that spin as they fall from the tree.
The Acer seeds are called “samaras,” “maple keys,” “helicopters,” “whirlybirds,” or “poly-noses.”
Acer trees are tapped in very early spring to gather the sap to be boiled down into maple syrup and further on to make maple sugar.
The US Army developed an effective carrier based on the shape of the Acer seed that could hold up to 65 pounds (29 kilograms) of supplies that were dropped from planes.
Homer’s hero of The Iliad, Achilles, was supposedly using Achillea filipendulina on wounded soldiers under his leadership.
In traditional Yi Jing (I Ching), dried Achillea millefolium stalks are tossed to create the shape that is used to divine the future.
It was also thought that if Achillea millefolium were once used in a wedding decoration and it was then hung over a marriage bed, seven years of true love would be assured.
Wear Achillea millefolium for courage and protection.
Carry Achillea millefolium to attract friends.
Achillea millefolium is used to banish evil from any place, any thing,and anybody.
The nickname of “Hot Water Plant” came about because some gardeners believed that hot water would shock the Achimenes plant into flowering.
Near the end of the ancient Roman period of European history, Aconitum napellus was banned. Anyone discovered to be growing it could have been legally sentenced to death.
In medieval times, Aconitum napellus was associated with witches.
For healing, string Aconitum napellus seeds like beads and wear them around the neck or wrist.
Carry Aconitum napellus seeds in a dried lizard’s skin to become invisible whenever you want to.
Acorus calamus was a favorite plant of Henry David Thoreau.
Walt Whitman wrote a section of poems inspired by Acorus calamus that were devoted to affection, love, and lust as an addendum to the third printing of Leaves of Grass, titled “Calamus.”
Acorus calamus seeds can be strung on thread as beads and worn for healing purposes.
Place a small piece of Acorus calamus in each corner of the kitchen to guard against poverty and hunger.
Sprinkle Actaea racemosa around the perimeter of your house or on door thresholds to protect your home against evil entering into it.
In the case of impotency, make a pouch of Actaea racemosa and carry it on you.
In the case of meekness, make a pouch of Actaea racemosa and carry it on you for strength.
The Adenium obesum can grow to be an unusual but beautiful small flowering tree with branches growing out from the top of a very thick trunk.
The Druids believed Adiantum could provide invisibility.

Legend tells that the goddess Venus cried so much for Adonis, who was suddenly killed by a wild boar while out hunting, that she was utterly inconsolable. The story is that wherever her fallen tears mingled with his blood, the Adonis plant is said to have emerged as a symbol of her sorrowful remembrance of her love for him and the fragile transience of life.
The Adoxa moschatellina received its nickname “Five-Faced Bishop” due to the way the inflorescence has five flowers, with one facing upward and the other four facing outward directly under it.

An old British children’s game called “Conkers” is played when Aesculus seeds are threaded on two separate pieces of string, with the two players taking turns to hit the opposing player’s seed until the conker breaks.
Aesculus hippocastanum seeds, or “conkers” as they are known, are believed to keep away moths and spiders if placed inside household furniture.

The non-toxic garden variety “Sweet Cicely” (Myrrhis odorata) is very similar looking to the highly poisonous Aethusa cynapium, making a serious point that looks, especially those that are beautiful, can often be dreadfully and dangerously deceiving.
Aframomum melegueta wishes are made by holding some of the herb in your hands, then you make your wish and toss a little in each of the four directions, beginning with north and ending with west.
Women of the Xhosa tribe make necklaces of dried Agapanthus roots to wear as fertility talismans and to ensure that strong, healthy babies will be born to them.
Agapanthus is believed to offer protection against the fear of storms and thunder.
Agathosma plants are prized for their pleasant herbal fragrance.
Agave plants grow so slowly that they became known as “Century Plant.”
When an agave plant is ready to bloom, it will send out a very tall “mast” from the crown of the plant, which buds and then blooms heavily toward the top of it.
Ageratum flowers appear to be fluffy puffs of petals.

powers: Sends spells back to the hexer
folklore: It is believed that if Agrimonia eupatoria is placed under the head of a sleeper, it must be removed for the sleeper to fully awaken.

It was believed that scattering Agrimonia eupatoria seeds would fend off witchcraft, especially if they were scattered around the perimeter of one’s home, carried in one’s pockets, or in a pouch around the neck or waist.
Agrimonia eupatoria is believed to determine if a witch is present or nearby.
Agrimonia eupatoria is said to be able to offer protection against evil, poison, and goblins as well as banish negative energies and negative spirits.

Poisonous Agrostemma githago was once such a common deadly scourge in grain fields that in the Middle Ages it was once written, “What hurt it doth among Corne, the spoile of bread, as well as in colour, taste, and unwholesomenesse, is better knowne than desired.” Since then agricultural advances in seed sorting have made strides in keeping Agrostemma githago seeds out of all cereal crop seeds. Even so, regular attention to field monitoring is a conscious duty of grain farming.
Ajuga foliage is dark-colored, crinkled, and glossy.
Alcea rosea is a beautiful, very tall, narrow plant with large flowers along its stalk that was often found in gardens, planted behind the shorter plants.

In the Middle Ages, drops of dew that were on the Alchemilla leaves were collected as they were considered sacred. These dew drops were used in magical potions, giving the Alchemilla the name “Dew-cup.”
Alchemilla is believed to have the ability to attract fairies.
A pillow containing Alchemilla or placing Alchemilla under a pillow supposedly promotes a good night’s sleep.
In the Middle Ages it was seriously believed that Alchemilla could actually restore a girl’s lost virginity.
Form crosses using Aletris farinosa roots and place them outside each entrance to your house if evil is plaguing your home.
Aletris farinosa has been carried to fend off evil.
Aletris farinosa is useful in uncrossing rituals and is believed to be an effective hex breaker.
The ancient Hawaiians would open the Aleurites moluccana, skewer the oily nutmeats (which are smaller than walnuts), then set them afire. These primitive “candles” burned for close to 45 minutes.
Native Hawaiians may still use Aleurites moluccana oil for lighting stone lamps.
All parts of the Aleurites moluccana tree have been deemed very useful in the day-to-day life of all Polynesian people.
The polished nuts (unpainted or painted), are strung as a beautiful lei to make a highly prized necklace.
There is no limit to how tall or wide an Allamanda vine can grow.
The flower of the narrow Allium plant is globular and the stem is tall, making it possible to tuck at least a few plants into even the most crowded garden.
The only time of the year that an Allium can be planted is in the autumn.
Allium ampeloprasum is believed to have been brought into south-west England and Wales by Prehistoric people.
The ancient Egyptians worshipped Allium cepa as the round shape, the layers, and the concentric rings when sliced symbolized eternal life and were included in burials.
In the Middle Ages, Allium cepa was so valuable that people gave bulbs as gifts and could even pay their rents with them.

Allium cepa is commonly used as an antidote for psychic attack or for sensing and then removing negative energy in the house. This is done by cutting one into quarters and placing the pieces where negativity seems evident, which is most often in the sleeping areas. Remove the Allium cepa quarters twelve hours later by taking the pieces all the way out of the house to throw them away. Use fresh Allium cepa every night.
Early American settlers would hang strings of Allium cepa over the doors to protect the inhabitants of the home from infections.

An interesting divination when you have a decision to make is using Allium cepa to do it for you. Using a separate Allium cepa for each option, carve a possibility on each bulb. Put them all in a dark place, checking them once each day. The first one that sprouts will provide the answer.
The “Land of Astolet” is part of Arthurian legend as being the location of Elaine’s castle, the lady who died of a broken heart due to her unrequited love for Sir Lancelot.
The earliest Sanskrit writings and also the Shih Ching (The Book of Songs), written by Confucius, mention Allium sativum.
A superstitious matador will wear a clove of Allium sativum on a string around his neck as protection prior to a bullfight.
To dream of Allium sativum is good fortune; to dream of giving away Allium sativum is bad luck.
Allium sativum wreaths outside a house’s door will ward off witches and psychic vampires.
A clove of Allium sativum worn on a string around the neck protects a traveler.
Allium sativum supposedly grew during a waning moon.
Sailors should carry Allium sativum on board to protect against shipwreck.
At one time, bunches of Allium schoenoprasum were hung in homes to repel evil spirits.
Early American Dutch settlers deliberately planted Allium schoenoprasum in the fields used for grazing their cattle so they could enjoy milk naturally flavored with the distinctive taste.
Although the leaves smell like onions when they are cut or crushed, the fragrance of the Allium tuberosum flower resembles that of a violet.
Appreciated for its bright tone, Alnus wood has been used for the bodies of Fender Stratocaster and Telecaster electric guitars since the 1950s.
Aloe vera has been planted on graves to help promote pre-reincarnation peacefulness.
Drawings of Aloe vera have been discovered on the walls of the tombs of Egyptian pharaohs.
There are ongoing studies into the extensive benefits of the Aloe vera plant.
Growing Aloe vera as a houseplant will protect against household accidents and evil.
Aloe vera hung over doors and windows will both keep out evil and bring in luck.
The brush-like flowers of Alopecurus pratensis resemble the bushy tail of a fox.
Aloysia citrodora can be added to your bathwater to purify yourself of negative energies.
Alpinia flowers and leaves are what give tropical floral arrangements their strikingly exotic look.
Carry or wear Alpinia galanga to foster your psychic abilities.
Carry or wear Alpinia galanga to pull in good luck to you.
Put Alpinia galanga into a leather pouch with silver coins to bring money.
To promote lust, sprinkle Alpinia galanga around the home.
Alstroemeria flowers have no fragrance.
Carry Althaea officinalis as a sachet to stimulate psychic power.
Althaea officinalis is believed to draw in good spirits.
A vase of Althaea officinalis in the window will bring back a lover who is straying.
Alyssum will expel negative charms if worn as an amulet.
Alyssum can calm an angry person if it is placed in their hand or on their body.
When Alyssum is hung in the house it supposedly can protect those in it against magically imposed illusions and fascinations.

In ancient Hawaii the only marriage tradition that existed (and continues as one of many new traditions practiced) is for the bride and groom to be brought in front of the Kahuna, who would wrap their joined hands with interlocking leis made of fragrant Alyxia oliviformis vines.
It is tradition in Hawaii for the groom and his groomsmen to wear Alyxia oliviformis leis.
In Hawaii a lei made of Alyxia oliviformis is suitable for all special occasions.
If someone were to wear a garland or wreath of this plant, it would facilitate invisibility for the wearer.
Ancient Greeks believed so intensely in the Amaranthus being a strong symbol of immortality that they would commonly spread Amaranthus flowers over graves.
Carry dried Amaranthus flowers to heal a broken heart.
Most often planted in garden borders, Amaranthus caudatus resemble curved chenille pipe cleaners.
Amaranthus hypochondriacus was once outlawed in Mexico by the Colonial Spanish because it was used in Aztec rituals.
A circlet of Amaranthus hypochondriacus flowers worn on top of the head is believed to accelerate healing.
Amaranthus hypochondriacus is believed to be able to cure a broken heart.
Wearing an Amaranthus hypochondriacus wreath will supposedly give the wearer the power of invisibility.
Dramatic and easy to force wintertime blooming indoors from a large bulb well within six weeks, Amaryllis will take six years to bloom when grown from seed.
In the wild, Amaryllis will bloom in spring or summer.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Your love is returned to you.

folklore: The pollen from Ambrosia artemisiifolia is the primary cause of misery for hayfever sufferers all over the world.
Plant Amorpha outside and around the home for protection.
Amorpha is useful in spells and amulets specific to protecting magical spiritual helpers.
Amorphophallus titanum roughly translated from Greek means “Giant Misshapen Penis.”
Amorphophallus titanum flower is the largest unbranched flower blossom in the world and will bloom only one day per year.
The corm of the Amorphophallus titanum flower weighs approximately 112 pounds (51 kilograms).
The fragrance of the open Amorphophallus titanum blossom smells like rotting mammal meat.
Anacamptis papilionacea is a ground orchid that can often be found growing in hay meadows.
In Brazil, “maranon,” better known as the “Cashew Apple,” is more popular than the nut, although it is not a true fruit, but the swollen stalk to which the seed of Anacardium occidentale is attached.
Anagallis arvensis only opens when the sun is shining.
It takes two years for Ananas comosus to produce a single fruit that resembles a pine cone.
Anastatica hierochuntica is both a tumbleweed and a resurrection plant. The process of curling and uncurling is completely reversible and can be repeated many times.
Anchusa officinalis attracts all kinds of prosperity.
Some legends claim that the same wind that passes over anemone flowers to open closed petals will be the same wind to blow the dead petals off of others.

The Anemone nemorosa has a long history of superstition behind it. In ancient times the Anemone nemorosa was thought to be the cause of all forms of pestilence, bringing diseases so deadly that people would run through a field in bloom, holding their breath, because they believed even the air around them would bring death.
The Chinese call the Anemone nemorosa “The Flower of Death.”
The early Egyptians considered Anemone nemorosa to be an emblem of sickness.

Long ago, the English once believed that the first Anemone nemorosa that one would set eyes upon should be picked, wrapped in a piece of clean white silk, and then carried as an amulet against pestilence.
In the Middle Ages, Anethum graveolens was frequently used in magic spells and witchcraft.
Hanging Anethum graveolens at a door offers protections against harm and will keep out anyone who is envious of you or unpleasant in nature.
A sprig of Anethum graveolens tucked on the cradle is supposedly able to protect the child in it.

powers: Renders witchcraft and the Evil Eye to be harmless
Wards off disasters of all types
folklore: Angelica archangelica is said to have protected entire villages during the Plague.
The fragrance of an angel is said to be exactly the same as that of Angelica archangelica leaves.
Angelica archangelica plants were planted at each of the four corners of a house or sprinkled as protection against all forms of wickedness and pestilence.
In a bath, Angelica archangelica will supposedly remove any kind of spell, curse, hex, or negativity that has been cast against the bather.
Gamblers have been known to carry Angelica archangelica in a pocket for protection against losing their money and luck at winning some.
Angelonia can be useful in spells seeking protection by angels in cases of deceit based on presumption.

The unusually long spur (11–17 inches) [2.5-43 centimeters] on the extraordinary star-shaped flower of the Angraecum sesquipedale, inspired Charles Darwin to predict (in an 1862 publication regarding his study of this flower) that the wild Angraecum sesquipedale would have to be pollinated by a then unknown moth with an unprecedentedly long-enough proboscis to reach the concentrated nectar at the end of the long spur. Darwin was ridiculed for his prediction. It was not until 21 years after Darwin’s death, in 1903, that his prediction was finally verified when the very large moth in question was discovered in Madagascar. It was named Xanthopan morganii praedicta, and is more commonly known as a the “Morgan’s Sphinx Moth.”
The vividly colored, velvety flowered Anigozanthos is the official floral symbol for Western Australia, where the plant grows wild.

generalSymbolicMeanings: All who know you will love you

folklore: Anthemis nobilis was considered a “plant doctor” and was planted near weaker plants to strengthen them.
Some gamblers wash their hands with an Anthemis nobilis infusion before gambling, hoping it will bring them winning luck.
The same Anthemis nobilis infusion can be used for bathing in the hope of increasing one’s chances of attracting love.
Sprinkling Anthemis nobilis infusion around the perimeter of one’s property is believed to have the power to remove curses and spells cast upon the residents who live there.

Anthoxanthum odoratum is considered a sacred plant that still holds significant importance to Native Americans, who burn it as an incense. Some Native American tribes consider Anthoxanthum odoratum to be the oldest of all plants and the hair of Mother Earth.
Anthoxanthum odoratum is often braided or left in bundles at burial and other sacred sites as an offering.
It was the Romans who spread Anthriscus cerefolium by planting it close to all its camps across the entire Roman Empire.
If you sense evil near you, step on or hold an Antirrhinum flower in your hand until you feel the evil pass by.
If someone has sent their negative energy to you or cursed you, place a vase of Antirrhinum flowers in front of a mirror and the negativity and curses will be sent back to the sender.
Wear Antirrhinum seed around your neck to protect yourself against being bewitched.
It was thought that if you hid an Antirrhinum on your person you would appear to be gracious and quite fascinating.
Wear or carry any part of an Antirrhinum to protect yourself against deception.
The ancient Greeks regarded Apium graveolens with the same esteem as Laurus nobilis (Bay Laurel), using it in wreath-making for the crowning of champion athletes.
Although highly toxic and utterly useless in so many other ways, abundantly blooming Apocynum is a highly valuable source of nectar for bees.
Aptenia cordifolia flowers open only during the sunny part of the day.
Aquilaria malaccensis attracts love if carried.
Aquilaria malaccensis has been used in magic for centuries to attract good fortune and bring love forward.
Due to the loss of its habitat in the wild and increasing illegal harvesting and trade, the Aquilaria malaccensis tree is so highly threatened that it is considered to be “extinct” in the wild.

Aquilaria malaccensis is the source of resinous agarwood, which is used in the making of perfume and incense and so spiritually significant that it is revered in the holy texts of all major religions in the world.

colorMeaning: Purple: Resolved to win.
Red: Anxious; Anxious and trembling; Trembling.

folklore: Aquilegia has been a symbol of foolishness because the flower looks like a jester’s cap with bells.
It is bad luck for the giver to give an Aquilegia flower to a woman.
Aquilegia is considered one of the most beautiful of all the wildflowers of the world.
Wear an Aquilegia flower for courage.
Put Aquilegia seeds in a small pouch and carry it to attract love.
If grown near the home or as a potted houseplant within the home, Araucaria heterophylla is believed to protect against evil spirits and hunger.
Araucaria heterophylla can grow 100 feet (30 meters) or taller and up to 60 feet (18 meters) wide.

generalSymbolicMeanings: You are the only one I love.

folklore: Arbutus regularly sheds bark, leaves, and berries.
Arbutus bark is rich in tannin that is used for tanning hides.
When Arubutus berries shrivel they grow barbs that attach to animals that unwittingly disperse them.
There have been reported incidences of bears becoming intoxicated from eating fermented Arbutus unedo berries that had been left on or under the trees.
The ancient Romans used Arbutus unedo to protect small children from evil around them.
Arctotheca calendula will germinate from autumn then gradually die off over the summer.

variantMeaning: / Arctium lappa burr: Rudeness; You weary me.

folklore: Velcro was inspired by an Arctium lappa burr.
Arctium lappa roots gathered during a waning moon, cut into short lengths, strung on a red thread, and then dried can be worn like a bead necklace as protection against negativity and evil.
Discreetly stick Arctium lappa burrs around the home to fend off negativity.
Wild bears are particularly fond of the Arctostaphylos uva-ursi fruit.
Arecaceae is the global iconic image that symbolizes the tropics and a get-away vacation.
Arenaria verna will grow into a thick, green living carpet.
Argentina anserina was once put into shoes to absorb perspiration.
Arisaema dracontium is considered to be a threatened and endangered plant in the wild.
A hooded hook-like spathe will emerge from above Arisarum to appear as a type of flower.
One side of the British three-pence coin is embossed with the image of Armeria.
Putting a piece of Armoracia rusticana in your purse or pocket during New Year’s Eve supposedly promises a year of adequate funds.
In Greek mythology it is written that the Oracle of Delphi once told Apollo that Armoracia rusticana was worth its weight in gold.

To clear all evil powers and dissipate negative spells cast upon your home, sprinkle ground dried Armoracia rusticana around the home, on the entry steps into the home, on every windowsill, and in every corner.
Artemisia abrotanum is considered the most potent antidote for magic potions.
Artemisia abrotanum is supposedly used to keep snakes and thieves away.
One of the beliefs about Artemisia abrotanum is that it can cause impotence in men.
In medieval times, a sprig of Artemisia abrotanum was very often included in bouquets presented by young men to girls as a secret mode of seducing them.
A sprig of Artemisia abrotanum placed under the bed is supposed to arouse lust.
It is believed that if Artemisia absinthium is burned in a graveyard it will induce the spirits of the dead to arise and they will speak to the conjurer.
There is a legend that Artemisia absinthium marked the path that Satan took on his exit from the Garden of Eden.
Artemisia absinthium is believed to offer protection against bewitchment.
Artemisia dracunculus is considered to be a desirable companion plant that protects the other plants near to it because its taste and scent is disliked by common garden pests.
Carry Artemisia dracunculus for good luck when hunting.
Carried, Artemisia vulgaris brings your journeying loved ones safely home and offers protection along the way from wild animals, sunstroke, and fatigue.
Carried, Artemisia vulgaris will also increase fertility and lust.
Artemisia vulgaris was thought to have magical powers and would be worn as protection from evil powers.
It was believed that if Artemisia vulgaris was collected on the evening before the Feast Day of Saint John the Baptist it would offer protection against evil, misfortune, and diseases.
It is believed that if you place Artemisia vulgaris in your shoes for long runs you will get strength from it.
A pillow stuffed with Artemisia vulgaris will give you prophetic dreams when you sleep upon it.
Place Artemisia vulgaris beneath or around a crystal ball to help with psychic readings while using it.
The ancient Japanese and Chinese once believed that the evil spirits of disease hated the smell of Artemisia vulgaris, so they would hang bunches of it over doors to keep illness out.
If put next to the bed, Artemisia vulgaris is supposed to help achieve astral projection.
Carry Artemisia vulgaris to prevent backache and cure madness.
Arundo donax has been used for flute-making for over 5,000 years.
Arundo donax is the primary material used for constructing reeds for woodwind instruments and bagpipes.

The Asclepias plant is the only plant that a Monarch butterfly will lay its eggs upon, because the hatched larvae caterpillar will feed on the leaves, absorbing the toxins that protect them from bird predators by making them distasteful.
Hummingbirds use Asclepias floss to line their nests.
Being six times more buoyant than cork, Asclepias floss was often used to stuff life jackets during WWII.

generalSymbolicMeanings: An attack against love for love

folklore: Despite its name, Asparagus densiflorus is not a vegetable or a fern.
Asparagus officinalis was depicted to be a type of ritual offering on an ancient Egyptian panel that dates back to around 3000 BCE.
Asphodeline is a sturdy, enduring plant that grows bigger and blooms better the longer it is left to grow in the ground.
Legend tells that Asphodeline was grown in the mythological Greek Underworld’s Elysian Fields, the final resting place for those who were heroic or especially virtuous.

generalSymbolicMeanings: I will be faithful unto death
My regrets follow you to the grave

folklore: According to ancient Greek legend, gray and gloomy-foliaged Asphodelus is associated with death and the afterlife, growing wild in the Underworld.
Asphodelus is often planted on graves.
Persephone’s garland crown is depicted as a wreath of Asphodelus flowers and foliage.

powers: Wish that things had turned out differently.
folklore: Carry Aster amellus to win love.
Grow Aster amellus in the garden as a wish for love.
Fluffy-plumed Astilbe flowers add texture and drama to a garden.
Plumed Astilbe stems dry well.
Astilbe chinensis has interesting fluffy plumelike blooms that dry well.
Astragalus presents an ongoing danger in any fields where grazing animals feed, affecting their minds in a way that makes the animal behave in an unnatural manner that seems “crazy” or “loco.”
In Finland, Astragalus glycyphyllos is considered to be a “critically endangered species” and is protected across the entire country.
All parts of the Atropa belladonna are deadly poisonous and should be completely avoided.
When Aurinia saxatilis flowers appear in spring, they will completely cover over the plant to obscure the foliage.
Colorful, pliable autumn leaves can be preserved to last indefinitely using any one of the easy crafting processes, such as completely coating them with a thin layer of wax.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Take care of yourself for me

folklore: The honey produced by bees collecting pollen from Azalea flowers is highly toxic.
Carve a wish on a piece of Bambusa vulgaris and then find a quiet place to bury it.

To protect the home and for good fortune, carefully carve the symbols of protection and good luck on a length of viable Bambusa vulgaris. Plant it in the ground near the house and then nurture it to grow.
Banksia laricina is a shrub that will grow to about 7 feet (2 meters) tall and will produce interesting, attractive, wavy “cones.”
If wind or water detaches the whole Bassia scoparia plant it can become a tumbleweed.
Begonia x tuberhybrida can be useful in encouraging potentially heated communications between parties to be calm and peaceful.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Gentleness on behalf of both giver and recipient
You have as many virtues as this daisy has petals.

folklore: Bellis perennis is a sentimental and much-loved flower among lovers, poets, and children.
It was once believed that if a Bellis perennis chain were wrapped around a child, the flower chain would protect the child from being stolen by fairies
If you sleep with a Bellis perennis root under your pillow your lost lover may return.
Wear a Bellis perennis flower to bring you love.
It was once believed that whoever it is that picks the very first Bellis perennis flower of the season will be uncontrollably flirtatious.
Bellis perennis flore plen flowers resemble cushy little pom-poms that have been flattened a little bit by the center.
Italian legend claims that Berberis was used in the Crown of Thorns that Jesus was forced to wear.
Carry a Bertholletia excelsa nut as a talisman to have good luck in love.
In Brazil it is illegal to cut down a Bertolletia excelsa tree.
Use Beta vulgaris juice to write words of love to a lover.
If a woman and a man eat of the same Beta vulgaris root, they will fall in love.
At one time cradles were made from Betula wood to protect the babies who slept in them from evil.
Gently strike a person suspected of being possessed with Betula twigs to cleanse and heal them of the affliction.
In Russia, it was a practice to tie a red ribbon around a Betula tree or branch, or around a twig to wear in order to repel or expel the Evil Eye from themselves.
A traditional witch’s broom was known to be made of Betula twigs.
Billardiera leaves are narrow and leathery.
The simple, five-point, bright blue Borago officinalis blossoms were a common subject carefully stitched into needlework designs.
To fortify your courage, carry Borago officinalis.
Wear a Borago officinalis flower when walking outdoors for protection.
The earliest known record of the use of frankincense (which is the aromatic resinous sap obtained from the Boswellia sacra tree) is inscribed on ancient Egyptian tombs.
The charred remains of burned frankincense is known as the eyeliner called kohl.

Incense has been used in the rituals of many different religions since ancient times, since it was believed that the smoke of the Boswellia sacra incense carried prayers and petitions directly upward.
Frankincense was discovered within a sealed flask in Pharaoh Tutankhamun’s tomb when it was opened in 1922. The incense was still viable, releasing scent after being in the vial for 3,300 years.
The used of frankincense is vital for magical purposes, such as atmospheric tonics, blessings, and initiation rituals.
Boswellia sacra has a very high and powerful vibration, which makes it one of the best of all herbs used to drive away evil.
Frankincense was written in the Holy Bible to be one of the three gifts offered by The Magi to the infant Jesus at the stable in Bethlehem.
At one time, Boswellia sacra was more valuable than gold.
The “flower” of the thorny, climbing Bougainvillea is not a flower at all, but a colorful cluster of three small leaves centered with a stamen that is called a “bract.”
If properly kept in fresh water, Bouvardia cut stems can last up to two weeks.
Brachyscome decipiens is a beautiful, little, colorful, daisylike flower that is naturalized in Southern Australia to bloom in cheerful mauve, purple, pink, white, and lemon colors.
The first thing that newlyweds should do to wish good luck on their marriage and on their garden is to plant Brassica oleracea.

variantMeaning.meaning: Good luck charm; Indifference; Visible faith.

folklore: Carry Brassica rapa seed in a red cloth pouch to increase your mental powers.
Bury Brassica rapa seeds under or near your doorstep to keep supernatural beings from coming into your home.
Briza blooms resemble the rattle tail of a rattlesnake and quiver with the slightest breeze.
Browallia speciosa grows nicely in a hanging basket to drape over the sides.
As a large shrub with huge, down-facing, trumpet-shaped flowers, Brugmansia is incredibly beautiful in full bloom, with a lovely fragrance both day and night.
Hang Bryonia root in the garden to protect it against damaging or bad weather.
To increase the amount of money you have, place some near a Bryonia alba and leave it there. When the money offering is removed from that location, the increase will cease.
Bryonia alba is believed to “scream” when it is pulled from the ground.
All parts of Bryonia alba are deadly poisonous.
Although butterflies are intensely attracted to the Buddleia flowers for the nectar, the plant does not support butterfly reproduction because caterpillars will not feed upon it.
Buddleia will wildly and widely grow along railroad tracks and in derelict areas, such as abandoned properties, to cheerfully indicate where attention is needed.
Buddleia earned the common name of “Bombsite Plant” in the United Kingdom, when the plants were found freely growing in city bomb sites following WWII.
Bursera graveolens is a wild tree that grows in parts of South America; it is in the same Burseraceae family as frankincense and myrrh.
“Palo Santo Oil” is the common name used for Bursera graveolens essential oil.
Dating back to the Inca era, according to some local Ecuadorian customs, Bursera graveolens is burned, like incense, to eliminate malevolent energy.
Bursera graveolens charcoal is occasionally used for smudging during some South American ritual customs.
Butomus umbellatus grows along the water’s edge of lakes, streams, and slowly moving rivers.
Buxus wood was once a choice wood for small finely constructed and carved boxes.
Buxus leaves are so small and dense that a witch cannot count the leaves, losing count and being forced to futilely start over and over again.
A Buxus hedge is said to be a distraction to a witch wanting to steal flowers from a garden.

generalSymbolicMeanings: My heart dreams come to fruition

folklore: Cactaceae grown indoors will protect the home against burglaries and intrusions.
Plant four Cactaceae plants outside the home, facing in each of the four directions, to protect it.
Cactacea spines have been known to be used to magically mark wax and soft roots with words and symbols, after which the marked item is either carried or buried.
Caladium are cultivated for their large, showy leaves.
Native to South America and naturalized in India and parts of Africa, nearly all commercial Caladium tubers are cultivated in Lake Placid, Florida.
The large, tough, and decorative Calathea leaves are occasionally used as small bowls for certain items.
A popular item that is crafted for home use in Thailand, and for colorful souvenirs, are Calathea leaf rice bowls.
Due to a “joint” in the stem of Calathea leaves, they will dramatically fold up at night and lift back up in the morning.
Calceolaria has a cute flower that resembles either a small “purse” or rounded “shoe.”
Carry Calendula officinalis petals with a Laurus nobilis (Bay Laurel) leaf to quiet gossip being passed around about you.
Calendula officinalis flower heads follow the sun like sunflowers do.
Early Christians would place Calendula officinalis flowers by statues of the Virgin Mary.
Calendula officinalis is considered to be one of the most sacred herbs of ancient India, where the flower heads were commonly strung into garlands and used in temples and at weddings.
Callisia fragrans is called “Inch Plant” because it “inches along” the ground, rooting wherever a plantlet touches soil.
Grow Callistephus chinensis to wish for love.
Carry a Callistephus chinensis flower to win love.
Wearing an amulet made of Calluna vulgaris wood will help facilitate awareness of one’s own true immortal soul.
Heather twigs were once used as brooms.
One of the two traditional plants used in the making of a witch’s broom was Calluna vulgaris (the other being Broom).
A sprig of Calluna vulgaris is carried as a protection charm against violent crimes, most specifically rape.
A sprig of white Calluna vulgaris is carried as a good luck charm.

powers: Methodical removal of one’s own magical power
Vivid exposure of one’s own pomposity.
folklore: The fruit of Calotropis procera is peculiar in that it is filled mostly with airy fluff that will cause it to burst when pressed.
In ancient times, the fiber that is attached to the Calotropis procera seeds are believed to have been used as candle and lamp wicks.
It is also believed that the fibers from the Calotropis procera fruit might have been used in the weaving of the fabric used in the garments worn by Hebrew high priests.
Caltha palustris is one of the first blooming and cheerful spring flowers, lifting the heavy spirit of drear after a long, dark winter.
There was a time when many a Southern belle would tuck a spicy fragrant Calycanthus blossom somewhere on herself.
Calystegia sepium is a clumping type of cactus that has large tubular-shaped flowers when it blooms.
It takes several years for a Camassia bulb to fully mature.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Good luck gift to a man

colorMeaning.meaning: Desire; Longing; Longing for you; Persistent desire.
Ardent love; In love; You’re a flame in my heart.
Adoration; Beauty; Loveliness; Perfection; Waiting; You’re adorable.

folklore: The Camellia was first introduced to America in 1797 to plant and beautify Elysian Fields in Hoboken, New Jersey, which is known to be the birthplace of organized baseball games in America.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Good luck gift to a man

colorMeaning.meaning: Desire; Longing; Longing for you; Persistent desire.
Ardent love; In love; You’re a flame in my heart.
Adoration; Beauty; Loveliness; Perfection; Waiting; You’re adorable.

folklore: Wear a pouch of Camellia sinensis as a talisman to increase your strength and give yourself a boost of courage.
Campanula flowers are bell-shaped and usually blue.
A Campanula medium flower resembles a fancy bell or an elegant teacup.
Campanula pyramidalis stalks will elegantly grow to around 6 feet (1.9 meters) tall, with the blue bell-like flowers in a spike along the top.
Whoever wears a Campanula rotundifolia flower will feel the need to tell the truth about anything.
The one you love will someday love you in return if you can turn a Campanula rotundifolia blossom inside out without damaging it.
Hummingbirds are attracted to the trumpet-shaped flowers of Campsis radicans.
Although the tree has a beautifully unusual fragrant blossom, common mistranslation of “flower of flowers” has been applied to Cananga odorata.
Since ancient times in China, ropes made from Cannabis sativa, more commonly simply called “hemp rope,” were used as proxy snakes to beat sickbeds with to drive out demons that cause illness.
The common names for Capsella bursa-pastoris are believed to have been inspired by the triangular flat shape of the plant’s fruit.
If you believe that you have had a curse placed upon you, encircle your house with red Capsicum to break the curse.
Cardamine is supposedly an ingredient in the “Nine Herbs Charm” of tenth-century England that was intended to be used in battle to fend off the perceived power used against them by the Serpent.
Cardamine pratensis is believed to be unlucky if brought into the home.
Cardamine pratensis is considered to be a sacred fairy flower.
Cardamine pratensis is not included in May Day wreaths and garlands so as not to offend the fairies, with the wearer being dragged under the ground into fairyland.
Each seed inside a puffy Cardiospermum halicacabum pod is marked with a white heart.
Wear or carry a Carduus blossom to rid yourself of feeling melancholy.
A vase of fresh Carduus in a room will renew the vitality of all who are within it.
Grow Carduus in the garden to fend off thieves.
Carry a Carduus blossom for protection against evil.
A man can carry a Carduus blossom to improve his lovemaking skills.
There was a time in England when a wizard would select the tallest Carduus they could find for use as a magic wand.
A piece of Carica papaya wood over the door will keep evil from entering the home.
Though both are called Paw-paw, Carica papaya and Asimina are not even remotely related to each other, with Carica papaya being the fruit that was the original “Paw-paw.”

generalSymbolicMeanings: Good luck in making a positive impression on judge and jury
Good luck in promoting love with marriage

folklore: If a man wants to get a positive response to his proposal of marriage, he should carry Carphephorus odoratissimus inside an amulet that he made for it out of red flannel cloth.
Carpinus produces a very hard, nearly white wood that is used where tough hard wood is required, such as for the gear pegs of windmills, tool handles, coach wheels, and more.
In the Middle Ages, Carum carvi was a common ingredient in love potions created to prevent lovers from turning and wandering away from each other.
Carum carvi seeds repels burglary. A thief who makes it into a house will be transfixed until arrested.
Wearing an amulet of Carum carvi seeds is supposed to improve the memory.
Tuck a small pouch of Carum carvi seeds in a hidden place in a child’s room as protection against illness.

A good charm to make to protect your home against trouble with the law is this: burn a piece of Carya ovata root until it is reduced to ashes. Mix the ashes with a little bit of Potentilla (Cinquefoil). Put the mix into a small box that you then hang over the entrance door(s) to your home.
Catalpa is an interesting ornamental tree with flowers that resemble orchids followed by long, bean-like seedpods.
As it is the only food consumed by the Catalpa Sphinx Moth, if there is an abundance of caterpillars, the Catalpa trees can be left completely void of leaves.
In ancient Greece, Catananche caerulea was the main ingredient in love spells.
The large, showy Cattleya flower is the most widely used flower in corsages gifted on Mother’s Day in America.
Smaller but still showy, the dwarf Cattleya pumila flowers are very often used in corsages gifted to a matron for any occasion.

variantMeaning.meaning: I live for thee; I live for you.
Constancy in love; I live for thee; I live for you.

powers: Cures the tendency to have bad dreams
folklore: A piece of Cedrus kept where you keep your money will draw more money to it.
A three-pronged stick of Cedrus libani can be pushed into the ground near the house with the prongs up to protect the home against all forms of evil.
A small piece of Cedrus libani placed wherever money is usually kept will draw money to it.

powers: Protection from witches practicing harmful magic
folklore: Celastrus scandens vine is highly poisonous.
Celastrus scandens was once commonly used to forcefully push malevolent magic, and witches who may be practicing it, away from the home.
Visually interesting in any garden, Celosia is a fun plant for children to grow due to its strange velvety or fluffy flowers.
The magic of the Celtis tree is that it will persuade someone to continuously do their best.
There was a time when Centaurea cyanus flowers were worn by men in love. If the flower faded too fast it was a sign that the man’s love would not be returned.
Centaurea moschata is sweetly scented with a fluffy petaled flower.
Centaurea scabiosa has thistle-like flowers that bees and butterflies are attracted to.
Centaurium was the plant of choice most often used in the making of vanishing potions.
Masses of tiny snow-white flowers cover the Cerastium tomentosum plant from late spring to early summer.
During ancient times in the Middle East, weighing gold and gemstones against Ceratonia siliqua seeds was common and also the source of the term “carat.”
Wear Ceratonia siliqua to guard against evil and maintain your good health.
Cercis siliquastrum is an exotically beautiful flowering tree that has been forevermore tagged with the legend that it is of the type from which Judas Iscariot hung himself by the neck.

powers: Encourages the magic of the evening

folklore: Cetraria islandica is actually a lichen that looks like a moss.
Pretty, fragrant Chamelaucium is a particularly well-meaning flower to include in a bridal couple’s wedding day flowers.
Fragrant Cheiranthus cheiri was one of the first flowers considered to be “romantic.”
There was a time, a few hundred years ago, when Cheiranthus cheiri was considered a valid currency for purchasing land in England.
If worn, Chelidonium will impart joy, good spirits, and cure depression.

Wear Chelidonium against the skin, replacing it every three days to escape any unwarranted imprisonments or entrapments of any kind. Wear Chelidonium to a court hearing as protection and to garner the favor of the judge and jury.
The Chenopodium bonus-henricus plant can be used to make natural dyes for natural fibers in the shades of dark golden-yellow to shades of green. Gold/green dyes can be obtained from the whole plant.
Chenopodium botrys is considered to repel moths via the fragrant flower spikes.
Carry or wear a sprig of Chimphila umbellata to attract money to you.
The open flowers of Chiranthodendron pentadactylon symbolize a human or monkey’s hand.
Chorizema varium is a pretty, happy-looking flower with a name rooted in Greek that means “dancing” and “drink.”

colorMeaning.meaning: I love; I love you; Love; Slighted love.
Imperial; Scorned in love; Slighted love.
