Chrysanthemum is a sacred flower in Asia.
In Malta and in Italy it is considered to be unlucky to have Chrysanthemum in the house.
The Chrysanthemum flower, both fresh and artificially stylized and constructed using mixed materials, is the somewhat official flower of American middle and high school “Homecoming” events.
Grow Chrysanthemum morifoliumin in the garden to fend off evil spirits.
To be more attractive to the opposite sex, add Chrysopogon zizanioides to the bath.
Place a sprig of Chrysopogon zizanioides in a cash register for more business.
Carry Chrysopogon zizanioides for luck.
If worn as a talisman to attract love, the fresh Cichorium endivia needs to be replaced every third day.

On Saint James’ Day (July 25), if a lock picker held Cichorium intybus leaves and a gold knife against a lock, it would magically open ONLY IF the deed was done in total silence . . . or else death would be the consequence for even a single word spoken.
Early American settlers would carry Cichorium intybus for good luck.
Carry a sprig of Cichorium intybus to promote frugality and to also remove the obstacles that stand between you and your goals.
It is said that if you bless yourself with Cichorium intybus juice then great people will pay attention to you and offer you favors.
Homeopathy, a form of alternative medicine, began upon Dr. Samuel Hahnemann’s testing of Cinchona bark.
Carry a small piece of Cinchona bark to protect yourself from evil and bodily harm.
Cinchona is the source of quinine.
Cineraria have the “rounded-mounded” look that florists like, because a blooming potted plant is covered over on all sides with flowers.
Ancient Hebrew high priests used Cinnamomum verum oil as a vital ingredient of a holy anointing oil.
The ancient Egyptians used Cinnamomum verum oil in mummification.
Cinnamomum verum used as incense or in a sachet provides the power to increase spiritual vibrations, help heal, bring in money, stimulate psychic powers, and provide protection.
Ancient Chinese and Egyptians used Cinnamomum verum to purify their temples.

Circaea lutetiana was named in honor of Circe, the daughter of the god Helios, who the Greek poet Homer wrote of in 800 BCE as being a cruel and terribly evil sorceress who enticed and welcomed shipwrecked sailors (and others) to her island before drugging them and turning them into animals (most frequently into pigs) which she then killed and ate.
Cistaceae is one of the thirty-eight plants used in the Bach Flower Remedies.
The entire Cistus ladanifer plant is covered with a sticky, dark, fragrant resinous sap that has been used in the making of perfumes since ancient times.
Citrullus lanatus was considered to be sacred in ancient Egypt.
Rub Citrus bergamia leaves on money before spending it to ensure that it comes back to you.
Put a few Citrus bergamia leaves wherever you carry your money to attract more.

variantMeaning.meaning: Discretion; Fidelity; Fidelity in love; I promise to be true; Prudence.

folklore: Add Citrus x limon juice to your bathwater during a full moon to purify yourself of negative energies.

variantMeaning.meaning: Bridal festivities; Brings wisdom; Chastity; Eternal love; Fruitfulness; Innocence; Marriage; Your purity equals your loveliness.

folklore: During the Victorian times, brides carried fresh Citrus x sinensis blossoms whenever possible, even wearing wreaths of the flowers or attaching the wreaths to their veils.
The Chinese considers Citrus x sinensis a symbol of good luck and good fortune.
Citrus x tangerina has been cultivated in China for over 3,000 years.

generalSymbolicMeanings: The variety of your conversation delights me.

folklore: Clarkia amoena was one of the first flowers that Lewis and Clark collected and documented when their expedition crossed the Louisiana Purchase.
The classical Greek name of Clematis was used in that long-ago time for a wide variety of any type of climbing plants.
Cleome blossom forms as a globe of flowers at the tip of the flowering stem, with each having very long stamens coming out of each flower, resulting in a “spidery” appearance.
An interesting evergreen shrub with unusual “beaked” buds and flowers, Clianthus puniceus has been determined to now be “critically endangered” in the wild.
The plant name of Clitoria was inspired by the flower being reminiscent of female genitalia.
A well-cared-for potted Clivia plant is known to live for up to fifty years.
Wear or carry a piece of Cnicus benedictus as protection from evil.
Cobaea scandens was observed and referenced in writing by Charles Darwin in 1875 with regard to his study of climbing and twining vines.

For protection, hang a whole Cocos nucifera nut in the home, or you can cut a Cocos nucifera nut in half, and fill it with other appropriate protection leaves, seeds, petals, and such. Close the two halves and reseal it however you can. Then bury it on your property.
Codariocalyx motorius leaves will “dance” when exposed to the sounds of music.
Coeloglossum viride is a terrestrial orchid with a spiked blossom of small green bracts that are reminiscent of little frogs.
Coix lacryma-jobi is a wild grass with seeds that are perfect beads with natural holes, so they can be easily strung and worn as jewelry.
Coix lacryma-jobi are also used inside hollow dried gourds to create shaker instruments.

To make a wish, concentrate on your wish while counting out seven Coix lacryma-jobi seeds, then carry them for seven days. At the end of seven days, make your wish once more, then throw the seven seeds into running water.
Despite the reference to “saffron,” Colchicum autumnale does not produce saffron, and has been known to be the source of acute poisoning for those who have dangerously mistaken it to be so.
Coleonema has very tiny flowers, reminiscent of confetti that landed on the bush.
The inflated seedpods of Colutea arborescens dry to be copper-colored puffed, papery, and somewhat fragile, but very interesting in a dried floral arrangement.

variantMeaning: / Commiphora gileadensis resin: Cure; Healing; I am cured; Love; Manifestations; Protection; Relief.

folklore: To heal a broken heart, carry Commiphora gileadensis buds.
Every part of the Conium plant is deadly poisonous, and for that reason it is too dangerous to use for any reason whatsoever.

colorMeaning: Pink: Fickleness; Lightness.
Purple: Haughtiness.

folklore: Consolida is believed to keep ghosts away.

powers: Power of people to visualize a better world.
folklore: Put Convallaria majalis in a room to uplift and cheer all the people in it.
As one of the most invasive wild plants, Convolvulus arvensis has been known to wreak havoc by reducing crop harvests to incur several millions of dollars of loss annually in America.
The primary source for obtaining jute fiber is the Corchorus plant.
Place a bit of the green variety of Cordyline fruticosa leaf under the bed to protect you when you sleep.
The Hawaiian hula skirt and Tongan dance dress is made up of the green variety of Cordyline fruticosa leaves.

In ancient Hawaii, the red variety of Cordyline fruticosa leaves were believed to have great spiritual power and only the high priests and chiefs were permitted to wear the red variety of Cordyline fruticosa leaves around their necks during rituals.
Bring the green variety of Cordyline fruticosa leaves on board the ship with you when traveling by water to ensure that you will not drown.
The green variety of Cordyline fruticosa was often used in ancient Hawaii to outline property borders.

Plant a Cordyline fruticosa border around your property as protection against evil, but be sure to only use the green variety and not the red variety for this purpose. The red variety is sacred to Pele and will give homeowners very bad luck if planted as protection, as they do not have the divine privilege to use it in this way.
To grow the red variety of Cordyline fruticosa in a pot in the home is considered to be extremely unlucky.
Fairies are believed to consider Coreopsis flowers one of their favorites.
The flowers of Coreopsis tinctoria can be used to make a light yellow to light brown colored dye for natural yarns.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Peace between those of us who do not get along.
variantMeaning: / Coriandrum sativum seeds: Promotes peace between people who do not get along.

powers: Protects gardeners and all those in their households
folklore: Hang a small bunch of Coriandrum sativum in the home for protection.
In the Middle Ages, Coriandrum sativum was used in love potions and spells.
Wear an amulet of Coriandrum sativum seeds to ease a headache.
The wood from the Cornus tree is so hard it can be used as a splitting wedge to split other woods.

It is believed that if you put a small amount of Cornus florida sap on a handkerchief on Midsunmmer Eve and then carry the handkerchief without fail, this will grant any wish you may have about anything.
Carry bits of Cornus florida wood or some leaves for protection.
Give Corylus avellana nuts to a bride to wish her good fortune, fertility, and wisdom.
Make a wishing crown by weaving Corylus avellana together. Wear this crown when making wishes.
A forked Corylus avellana branch is the diviners’ dowsing rod of first choice.
Corylus maxima is believed to have been given the common name “Filbert” because the tree’s nuts matured on August 20th, which is the Feast Day of Saint Philbert.
Cosmelia rubra are indigenous to the swamps of southwestern Australia.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Hold my hand and walk with me
Joy in love and in life

folklore: Arrange a Cosmos bipinnatus bouquet in a home that needs spiritual harmony restored within it.
Cotinus coggygria flowers are very fluffy looking and a grayish-beige color that gives the canopy of the tree a smoke-like appearance.
Crassula ovata is and always will be the primary “money plant.”
Crassula ovata will be especially “lucky” when it blooms.

There is a legend that Joseph of Arimathea went to Britain to carry the message of Christ there. At one point, he pushed his staff in the ground to sleep nearby. When he awoke he discovered the staff had taken root, grown, and blossomed into a Crataegus tree.
The Romans attached Crataegus leaves to baby cradles to repel evil spirits.
In medieval Europe, if Crataegus branches were brought inside it was an omen of illness and death for one member of the household.

Crataegus is considered one of a witch’s favorite plants. In the spring on Walpurgis Night (Walpurgisnacht), when witches supposedly turn themselves into Crataegus trees, the Crataegus is to be avoided.
Because of its correspondence with fertility, Crataegus has been added into spring wedding flowers.
Put Crataegus under a mattress and around a bedroom to maintain or even enforce chastity.
Tuck a Crataegus leaf into your hat to promote a good catch when fishing.
Wear a spring of Crataegus if troubled, sad, or depressed to help return you to a state of happiness.
Sprigs or leaves of Crataegus placed around the home will protect it against lightning and storm damage.
Sprigs or leaves of Crataegus placed around the home will protect against evil, and malicious ghosts.
Crataegus is sacred to fairies.
It is believed that one will be able to see fairies where these three trees grow together: Crategus, Quercus (Oak), and Fraxinus excelsior (Ash).
In India, Crocus sativus flowers are often scattered on the marriage bed of newlyweds.
During the Bronze Age, Crocus sativus was used in Minoan religious rituals, to later be adopted, over time, by other religions for their own religious rituals.

Once a Crocus sativus was smuggled into England (then throughout Europe) from the Middle East inside a walking stick, its value was considered priceless. Changing it, by adding to it anything of a lesser value, to increase its quantity but lower the quality, was punishable by horrible deaths. . . including being buried alive!

When Crocus sativus reached India, it was discovered, there that a beautiful golden-colored dye could be rendered from it for fabrics, the color of which is used for royal garments in many different countries and cultures.
During the Middle Ages, inks made from Crocus sativus were used by the poorer illuminators to replace gold leaf in their religious art renderings.
There was a time in Ireland when the bed linen was rinsed with an infusion of Crocus sativus with the belief that the arms and legs would be made stronger while sleeping upon them.
Ancient Persians would toss Crocus sativus into the air as an attempt to raise the wind.
It is believed that you can attract love by growing Crocus vernus.
From a small potted houseplant to an exterior tree-size plant, many Croton varieties are very colorful.
For household protection, and an increase in money and luxury, grow a Cryptanthus plant inside the home.
Roman midwives would carry Cucumis sativus, then throw them away when they delivered a baby.
Roman wives, desiring a baby, would wear Cucumis sativus around the waist.
Roman households used Cucumis sativus to frighten away mice that would enter into their homes.

Jack-o’-lanterns for Halloween would not be quite the same without Cucurbita pepo to use for their carving, originally made in Ireland to put out on the front step to scare away the Devil and any other sinister spirits that may come near.
Cuminum cyminum will supposedly prevent the theft of anything that has this spice on or in it.
Mixed with salt and scattered on the floor, Cuminum cyminum will supposedly drive out evil.
A sprig of Cuminum cyminum is sometimes worn by a bride to keep any negativity away on her wedding day.
Carry Cuminum cyminum for peace of mind.
Wear a sprig of Cupressus for comfort to ease the mind of grief upon the death of a friend or relative.
Since it is such a strong symbol of immortality, growing Cupressus provides blessings and protection.
In every part of India, Curcuma longa is considered to be very lucky and has been used in Indian weddings and religious ceremonies for thousands of years.

A love divination that might work is to pluck a large sprig of Cuscuta, then throw it over the shoulder at the plant you picked it from while asking if the person you love loves you in return. Leave, then return the next day and examine the sprig. If it has not reattached itself, your answer is no. If the sprig has reattached, then the answer is yes.
If grown in a bedroom, Cyclamen is believed to protect those sleeping and no negative spells can have any power there.
Art seen in the excavated remains of Pompeii has revealed images of bears carrying Cydonia oblonga fruit in their paws.
To carry even one Cydonia oblonga seed will protect you against accidents, evil, and harm against your body.
Cylindropuntia imbricata is a tree-size cactus with many branches covered with dangerous spines.
Australia considers the infestation of Cylindropuntia imbricata dangerous to humans and animals, declaring it to be a “noxious weed.”
The leaves of the Cymbidium indicate their lighting health-dark green leaves indicate they need more light, yellow leaves indicate they are getting too much light.
Cymbopogon planted around the home is believed to repel snakes.
The Cyperus papyrus plant has great historical fame, as it is the plant that the ancient Egyptians used to make papyrus paper.
It was believed that Cyperus papyrus inside a boat would protect it from attack by crocodiles.
Carry Cypridedium within an amulet to provide personal protection.
Hang Cytisus scoparius outside the home to keep evil from entering into it.

The legend of Daphne is Greek in origin and goes all the way back to Eros, who shot two arrows: a gold one striking Apollo, who had mocked Eros and who then fell madly in love with beautiful Daphne, the daughter of a river god; and the other made of lead, striking virginal Daphne (who wanted to remain so for all her life), which provoked Daphne to despise Apollo incessantly—so much so that Daphne begged Aphrodite to save her from Apollo’s tormenting lust. Aphrodite complied by turning Daphne into a tree, which did not stop Apollo from loving her forever.
Daphne cneorum flowers are pink and spicy scented.
Daphne mezereum is a very common plant that very few people realize is poisonous.

generalSymbolicMeanings: I would not have you otherwise
Make beautiful that which is beautiful
Unnecessarily make beautiful that which is beautiful.

folklore: Daphne odora has sweetly scented, reddish-purple-pink flowers with a fragrance that will linger in the air.
Datura is extremely poisonous.
Datura has the ability to change according to the location where it is growing —the size of plant, leaf, and flowers.
Daucus carota, known as Queen’s Anne Lace, is named so after England’s Queen Anne, who was a renown expert lace maker.
One dreadful superstition is that if someone picks Daucus carota, then brings it into their home, their mother will die.
Another superstition is that if a woman who is true to herself plants Daucus carota in her garden, the plant will thrive.
In the Caribbean, the seedpods of Delonix regia are used as a percussion shaker instrument, which is a type of maraca.

Both the red-orange and the rarer yellow Delonix regia trees are so much one of the most beautiful showy flowering ornamental trees in the world that it is the official tree of several Asian countries and appears on the emblem of a university.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Ability to transcend the bounds of space and time

colorMeaning: Pink: Pure love.
Red: Ardent love; Pure love.
White: Ingeniousness; Talent; You are fair.
Yellow: Disdain; Unreasonableness.
Variegated: Refusal.
variantMeaning: / Dianthus double flower: Unchanging love.

folklore: Because of their fragrance and being so easy to grow, Dianthus is one of the oldest flowers ever cultivated.
Dried Dianthus flowers can be added to potpourri and sachets.
Dianthus barbatus, better known as “Sweet William,” symbolizes the brokenhearted lovelorn men mentioned in some old English stories and ballads.

colorMeaning: Pink: A mother’s love; A mother’s undying love; A woman’s love; Always on my mind; Deep love; I’ll never forget you; Mother’s Day symbol; Sentimental love; Woman’s love.

Red: Admiration; Admiration from afar; Affection; Alas! For my poor heart; Ardent love; Deep romantic love; Desire; Desires that never come to pass; Forlorn; My heart aches for you; Poor heart; Pure; Pure and ardent love.
Light Red: Admiration.
Dark Red: Affection; Alas for my poor heart; Deep love.
Deep Red: Affection; Alas for my poor heart; Deep love.
Mauve: Dreams of fantasy.
Purple: Antipathy; Capriciousness; Changeability; Changeable; Condolences; Unreliability; Whimsical.
White: Disdain; Faithfulness; Innocence; Good luck; Pure love; Purity; Sweet and lovely; Sweet love.
Yellow: Disappointment; Disdain; Rejection; Unreasonableness; You have disappointed me.
Solid: Acceptance; Affirmative; I want to be with you; Yes.
Striped: No; Refusal; Regret that love cannot be reciprocated; Rejection; Sorry, I can’t be with you.

folklore: In ancient Greece, Dianthus caryophyllus were the most loved of all flowers.
A corsage or nosegay made up of a Dianthus caryophyllus, a sprig of Rosmarinus officinalis, and a Geranium flower means: Love, Fidelity, and Hope.
Fresh red Dianthus caryophyllus in the room of a convalescing patient will promote strength and energy.
Wearing a Dianthus caryophyllus flower was popular during Elizabethan times because it was believed that the flower helped prevent being put to death on the scaffold.
Dianthus chinesis are low-growing plants with cute flowers that have serrated-edged petals.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Vowing into dense low puffs, Diapensia lapponica is known to exclusively grow in the alpine meadows, on mosses, around and in the crevices of large rocks, and along the trails found on the highest peaks of the Adirondack Mountains.

folklore: Certain Rediviva bee species coexist with the wild Diascia plant, evolving to have longer forelegs used specifically for the gathering of a special oil found in the spurs of the flower.

The volatile oils in Dictamnus albus is such that the plant is easily combustible in hot weather. Because of this natural tendency, it is a contender for being the “burning-bush” referred to in the Bible.
Superstition implied that it was once believed that a witch could use Dierama to transform into a hare to hide among Bluebells (Hyacinthoides non-scripta).

generalSymbolicMeanings: I am ambitious only for you

folklore: There is a legend that fairies wear Digitalis purpurea blossoms as mittens.
According to superstition, if you pick a Digitalis purpurea, the fairies will be offended.
Medieval witches kept Digitalis purpurea growing in their gardens because they were a regular ingredient in spells.
At one time Welsh housewives would create a black dye using the Digitalis purpurea leaves that they would use to paint crossed lines on the outside of their houses to fend off evil.
Digitalis purpurea is believed to be a favorite of fairies because they like to wear the flowers as hats.

Although there are a few naturalized areas of plants growing in some specific U.S. areas in northern Florida and New Jersey, the carnivorous Dionaea muscipula is native only within a 60-mile (97 kilometer) radius surrounding Wilmington, North Carolina.
All parts of Dioscorea communis are highly poisonous, but are used as a principal ingredient in the making of birth control pills.
Touching Dioscorea communis can cause painful blisters.
A wand made of Diospyros will give a magician undiluted pure power.
An amulet made from Diospyros will offer protection to the wearer.
It is believed that to be rid of the chills you should tie one string to a Diospyros tree for each chill you’ve experienced.
Bury a green Diospyros fruit for good luck.
Before the twentieth century, the sturdy dried teasels of Dipsacus fullonum were used in the weaving industry for combing, cleaning, aligning, and raising the nap of certain fibers and fabrics.

Some believe that Dipteryx odorata beans can grant wishes by holding a bean in the hand while whispering the wish to it, then carrying the bean until the wish comes true . . . then burying or stomping on the bean afterwards. Another method is that the wished-upon bean is buried in a fertile, hospitable location and the wish will come true during the time that the plant is growing.

Radio-carbon dating of large Dipteryx odorata stumps left behind by loggers in the Amazon proved that Dipteryx odorata is definitely a species of tree that could live to a great age . . . over 1,000 years!
Dracaena resin is often used as an ingredient in the making of a specific wood sealant that is used to varnish violins.
Dracaena arborea can have one head or be a multiple-headed dragon on the same trunk.

Being that the resinous sap of Dracaena cinnabari is crimson red, it was highly prized as being “Dragon’s Blood” in the ancient world. Therefore it was, and still is, commonly used in ritual magic and alchemy.
To quiet a boisterous home and impose peace and order, put equal parts of powdered Dracaena cinnabari, salt, and sugar in a tight-fitting jar and then hide it in the house where it cannot be found.
Dracaena cinnabari is used for religious purposes in American hoodoo, New Orleans voodoo, and African-American folk magic.
Dracaena cinnabari resin is added to ink to create “Dragon’s Blood Ink,” which is used to inscribe magical talismans and seals.

Feng Shui practitioners believe that Dracaena sanderiana represents the wood and water elements. A red ribbon tied around the plant’s stalks incorporates the element of fire and ignites the positive flow of chi in the room. Take care to use the correct number of Dracaena sanderiana stalks, as three is for happiness, five is for wealth, and six is for health. Do not use four stalks because the word “four” sounds like the word “death” in Chinese, and therefore it should especially be avoided in this particular circumstance.

The flower of Dracunculus vulgaris is sinisterlooking and smells like a dead animal, so it attracts such insects as flies and carrion beetles that are so confused by the stench that they lay their eggs upon the flower, presuming the rotting “meat” will feed the maggots— nourishment that the plant will not provide for the larvae.
Carry a piece of Drimys winteri for success in whatever you do.
Due to its beautiful reddish color and heavy weight, Drimys winteri is used for furniture and instruments.
Drosera rotundifolia is a carnivorous plant that feeds on insects that become attracted to them, then get stuck upon the sticky hairs that cover the leaves.
Dryopteris filix-mas was often an important addition to the making of a potent love potion.
Drypetes deplanchei wood has been used to make bullwhip handles.
Since the sap of Drypetes deplanchei effectively repels sea worms, the wood was once used for the construction of sea piles by the early settlers of Lord Howe Island in the Tasman Sea.
With lavender-blue flowers and visually alluring berries, Duranta erecta is a very pretty poison that has already been proven to have killed children and pets.
The Javanese people have long believed that the fruit of the Durio is a reliable aphrodisiac.
Durio flowers are closed during the day and open at night, so they can be pollinated by fruit bats.

In Southeast Asia, it is forbidden to bring the Durio fruit (which is known as “Stinky Fruit” for a good reason) into many hotels, airports, restaurants, subways, and on nearly all public transportation.
Echeveria offshoots form the “chicks’ that grow off from the mother “hen” roseling.
Echeveria plants serve as host plants for some butterfly species.
Digging up a wild Epigaea repens plant will result in a fine in Massachusetts and Nova Scotia, where it is their floral symbol.
The Native American Pottawatomi people believe Epigaea repens is divinely present and consider it to be their official tribal flower.

Because Epilobium angustifolium can establish itself rapidly upon burnt ground, the abandoned bomb sites, in sharp contrast to their grim reminders, were very quickly covered over with this prolific flowering plant.
Epiphyllum will climb up a sturdy tree to thrive in the shade to blossom strongly fragrant, extremely showy, night-blooming flowers that will bloom for one night only and then die.
The flowers of the Eremurus are atop a tall spike that resembles a “bottle brush.”
Erigeron hung over the doors will keep evil from entering.
Carry a sprig of Eriodictyon californicum to attain beauty.
Because Euruca sativa was considered an effective aphrodisiac for both men and women as far back as the days of ancient Rome, in the Middle Ages it was forbidden to be grown in monastery gardens.
Carry Eryngium when traveling as a charm for luck and safety.
Scatter Eryngium wherever people are quarreling, to promote peace between the battling parties.

Although Erythroxylum coca has been outlawed in many countries, its daily use has played a role in South American religious rituals and communal life for thousands of years (particularly in the Andes region).
Eschsholzia flowers have yellow or vivid orange petals.
Eschsholzia flowers close on cloudy days.
Carry Eucalyptus leaves to maintain good health.
Hang a piece of Eucalyptus over a sickbed to encourage healing.
To the Aboriginal people of Australia, Eucalyptus is sacred in that it represents the division of Earth from Heaven and the Underworld.
Native to Tasmania and Victoria, Australia, Eucalyptus regnans is the tallest flowering plant in the world.
Gigantic Eucalyptus regnans is the second-tallest tree in the world, with Sequoia sempervirens of North America being the tallest.
After a forest fire, unlike many other types of trees, Eucalyptus regnans cannot produce ground shoots as a means of recovery, so it must be replenished via seed.
There was a time when Eucharis was used in bridal wreath-crowns.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Your charms are graven on my heart
Your image is engraved on my heart.

folklore: The bright, colorful Euonymus wood was once used to make spindles.
Euonymus was named in honor of Euonyme, who is believed to be the Mother of the Fairies.
Carry Euonymus atropurpureus for courage.
Eupatorium wards off evil spirits if sprinkled around the home.
Euphorbia is a very poisonous plant and care should be given to it.
Grown indoors or outside, Euphorbia is considered to be a protective plant.
Native to Mexico, the colorful red, pink, orange, green, white, or marbled flowers of Euphorbia pulcherrima plants are not flowers at all, but leafy colored bracts.
Aztecs used Euphorbia pulcherrima to produce dye.
The association of Euphorbia pulcherrima with Christmas began in the sixteenth century.
Euphorbia pulcherrima plants and flowers, both real and artificial, are a standard decoration during the Christmas holidays.
Carry Euphrasia when it is needed to see the truth in any matter.
Carry Euphrasia to increase psychic powers.
Carry a few Eutrochium leaves to encourage those you meet to look upon you favorably and respectfully.
Eutrochium has strange, hairy-looking, fragrant flowers.
When in close proximity to any thorn or thorny plant, proceed alertly and with caution.
Convert Fagopyrum esculentum grains into a powder, then sprinkle this flour around the entire perimeter of your house to keep evil from it.
According to Tahitian legend, the flowers of the Fagraea berteroana tree’s fragrance is heavenly because it originated in the Tenth Heaven.
Fagraea berteroana is often used to create beautiful, fragrant Hawaiian leis.
Carry Fagus leaves or a piece of its wood to promote and increase creativity.
To make a wish, carve it on a Fagus stick then bury it. If the wish is meant to be, it will be.

powers: Evoke demonic forces and bind them
folklore: Ferula assa-foetida is believed to destroy all manifestations of spirits.
Ferula assa-foetida has one of the most horrible odors of all herbs and merely the scent of it is known to induce vomiting.
Carry a piece of Ferula moschata to attract love.
Biblical legend says that it was the leaf of a Ficus tree that was used to cover Adam and Eve’s perceived nakedness from God’s eyes.
To be married beneath a Ficus benghalensis tree brings happiness and good luck to the couple.
To sit under a Ficus benghalensis tree will bring good luck.
To look at a Ficus benghalensis tree will bring good luck.
With regard to the area occupied by a single tree, which can cover acres of land, Ficus benghalensis is, without question, the biggest tree in the world.

Ficus carica leaves were what Adam and Eve supposedly clothed themselves with in the Bible’s Book of Genesis. As a consequence, Ficus carica leaves were often used to modestly cover the genitals of many other nude figures in artworks throughout the ages.
For both men and women, to increase fertility and also to overcome any sexual incompetence, carry a small phallic carving made using Ficus carica wood.

Legend tells that Siddhartha Bautama was sitting under a Ficus religiosa tree at the time of his enlightening. He sat under it for six years. A direct descendant of this particular tree is enshrined within the Mahabodhi Temple in Bodh Gaya, India, and it is a frequent destination for Buddhist pilgrims.
It takes approximately 102 to 500 years for a Ficus religiosa tree to be fully grown.
The Ficus religiosa tree has very distinctive heart-shaped leaves.
Religious Buddhist art can be found painted on Ficus religiosa leaves.
Ficus religiosa leaves are often possessed as sacred treasures.
Walk around a Ficus religiosa tree several times to make evil flee.
As one of the few trees mentioned in the Bible, Ficus sycomorus is referred to seven times in the Old Testament.
To protect the trees, King David commissioned a careful watch over Ficus sycomorus.
Ficus sycomorus was referred to as being killed by frost during the biblical plagues upon the ancient Eypgtians.
Ficus sycomorus is a sacred tree to the Kikuyu people.
Filipendula ulmaria was the preferred floor-strewing herb of Queen Elizabeth I.
Evidence of Filipendula ulmaria was found with cremated remains dating back to the Bronze Age in Wales.
Extensive veining on the Fittonia argyroneura leaf resembles a cluster of nerves.
Plugging keyholes with Foeniculum seeds is thought to keep ghosts from entering.
Hanging Foeniculum at the windows and doors will keep evil spirits from entering.
Carry Foeniculum seeds to keep evil spirits away from you.
The blooming of Forsythia at the start of spring presents the cheerful yellow-flowered branches as a welcome sight after winter.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Good luck of the best kind
What glitters may not be gold.

folklore: The Fortunella japonica fruit has an appealing sweet peel with a very tart interior that can imply to some senders and recipients, “that which glitters like gold may not truly be gold.”
Carry Fragaria vesca leaves for good luck.

variantMeaning: / Fragaria x ananassa blossom: Love; Luck.

folklore: Franciscea latifolia flowers start out being purple but fade to a lavender shade, then white.

In Norse mythology a mythical Fraxinus excelsior called “Yggdrasil” is considered to be the center of the world, with its roots in the underworld to be watered by wisdom and faith; with the trunk supporting the earth and the canopy touching the arch of heaven.
If going out to sea, carry a solar cross carved from Fraxinus excelsior wood as protection against drowning.
A Fraxinus excelsior staff placed over doors and windows is used as protection against sorcery.
Burn a Yule log of Fraxinus excelsior for prosperity.
Carry Fraxinus excelsior leaves to gain love from the opposite sex.
Placing Fraxinus excelsior leaves under a pillow is believed to promote prophetic dreams.
Scatter Fraxinus excelsior leaves in all four directions near the home to protect the house and the entire area around it.
Placing fresh Fraxinus excelsior leaves in a bowl of water beside the bed overnight, then discarding them in the morning, is supposedly a preventative against illness.

colorMeaning: Pink: Motherly love.
Red: Passion.
White: Innocence; Purity.
Yellow: Joy.

folklore: Freesia will grow as tall as Gladiola before it begins to bud into flower, and the top end of the stem will bend nearly ninety degrees to bloom horizontally.

Unlike any other purchased cut flowers that are brought in to display in water, trimming the bottom of the Freesia stem before placing in the water will bring the quick demise of the blossom, due to a strong release of ethylene gas from the stem itself.
To avoid a quick demise of Freesia, do not place it next to any Narcissus in an arrangement.
In the spring, blooming Fritillaria imperialis emit an odor that smells like fox to rodents and other small creatures, to effectively repel them.
In England, the natural habitat of wild Fritillaria meleagris is fairly limited to what are known to be ancient hay meadows.

generalSymbolicMeanings: The ambition of my love thus plagues itself.

folklore: The dangling, pendant-like flowers of Fuchsia resemble elaborate earrings.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Call on the winds over the sea for help.

folklore: Fucus vesiculosus, a seaweed most commonly found on the shores of the British Isles, is also found on beaches of the western Baltic Sea, the North Sea, the Atlantic Ocean, and the Pacific Ocean.
Fucus vesiculosus is the original source of therapeutic iodine.
Carry a Fucus vesiculosus amulet when traveling on or over the sea as protection.

There is a superstition that it is unlucky to bring Galanthus nivalis into the home, and that supposedly merely the sight of a single Galanthus nivalis growing in the garden foretold a pending disaster.
Due to the heart shape of the leaves, Galax urceolata has been overused in floral arrangements involving love and marriage, resulting in over-harvesting of the leaves in the wild.
Galax urceolata grows mainly in forest shade high up in the Appalacian Mountains.

colorMeaning: Purple: First emotions of love; Love at first sight.

folklore: It is believed by some that putting Galega officinalis leaves into your shoes will prevent rheumatism.

variantMeaning: / Galium aparine burr: Cling to me.

folklore: Carry Galium odoratum to attract money.
Carry Galium odoratum as protection against harm.
Carry a sprig of Galium odoratum to be victorious in sports or battle of any kind.
Wear or carry a sprig of Galium triflorum to attract love.
The legend is that Galium verum was the hay used in the Bethlehem manger where Jesus was placed as a newborn.
In days of old, dried Galium verum was often used as a mattress stuffing because it was thought to be a fairly effective flea killer as well.
Wear or carry a sprig of Galium verum to attract love.

Due to the extremely high spiritual vibrations of Gardenia jasminoides, you can float a blossom in a bowl of fresh water or scatter dried petals around the room to promote a sense of extreme inner peacefulness and increased spirituality.
It is believed that a sprig of Gaultheria procumbens under a child’s pillow offers protection and a life of good fortune.
The Gaultheria shallon branches and leaves are much desired by florists, who refer to them as “Lemon Leaf.”
Light-sensitive Gazania rigens flowers close when it is dark, and may only partially open on cloudy days.
Yellow jasmine is always poisonous, with the flowers of Gelsemium sempervirens being mistaken by children who have been poisoned when tasting the nectar droplet of a flower.
Gelsemium sempervirens is known to be toxic to honeybees.
Gentiana andrewsii flowers stay closed to look as if they are in bud.
There is a superstition that snakes and flies will not go near Geraniums that are white.
Geranium phaeum has very, very dark purple flowers with turned-back petals that appear nearly black.
The plump stem of the Gerbera flower is hollow and relatively fragile.
If worn as an amulet, Geum urbanum protects against attacks by beasts, dogs, and venomous snakes.
Gladiolus grew wild in the Holy Land and along the coast of Africa so abundantly that they are thought to be the actual “Lilies of the Field” that Jesus spoke of in his Sermon on the Mount.
To find out who is working against you using negative magic, starting on a Tuesday, encircle a yellow candle with Glechoma hederacea and then light the candle. The knowledge will come to you.
European settlers eventually and successfully carried seeds and cuttings of Glechoma hederacea all around the world.
Gleditsia triacanthos is a very tall, terrifyingly thorny, flowering tree that has a wide canopy and can live up to 100 years.

The thorns that are single or branching out completely cover the trunk, and all branches of Gleditsia triacanthos are usually 2 to 4 inches (5 to 10 centimeters) long, with some reaching 8 inches (20 centimeters) long.
In the era of wooden ship building, the hard thorns of the Gleditsia triacanthos were often used as nails.
Gloxinia plants need to be hydrated with tepid water because they are highly sensitive to cold.
Carry a piece of Glycyrrhiza glabra root to attract love.
Glycyrrhiza glabra is believed to make a good wand.
Gnaphalium leaves can survive being frozen over during winter.
Carry and/or keep Gnaphalium uliginosum in the home to help prevent illness.
Gomphrena globosa flowers are used in long-lasting Hawaiian leis because they hold their shape and color long after the flowers have dried.
Gossypium that is either scattered or planted on your property will keep ghosts away.
Gossypium cloth should be your first choice when you require cloth for magical purposes.
Burning a piece of Gossypium supposedly will bring rain.
A piece of Gossypium in the sugar bowl brings good luck.
Throw Gossypium over your right shoulder when the sun rises and it will bring good luck that day.
Little balls of Gossypium that have been soaked in white vinegar and placed on all the windowsills will keep evil from entering.
Petal-less flowers on a long calyx give Grevillea the stylized appearance of toothbrush bristles.
The national flower of Costa Rica is Guarianthe skinneri.
With its full clusters of tiny delicate flowers, Gypsophila has been a long-time favorite of brides.
A forked twig of Hamamelis wood is what is most commonly used as an effective divining rod.
Carry a sprig of Hamamelis to heal a broken heart.
Two very long stamens emerge from each tiny flower along the long cluster of a showy, blooming, Hebe speciosa bush flower stalk.

variantMeaning: / Hedera helix sprig: Longings.
/ Hedera helix sprig of tendrils: Affection; Anxious to please; Assiduous to please.

folklore: Hedera helix was once carried by women to bring luck.
Hedera helix is a symbol of eternal life to both pagans and Christians.
If Hedera helix is blended with Ilex aquifolium (Holly) at Christmas it is thought to bring peace to husband and wife in their home.
Hedera helix can climb up into the canopy of trees and grow so densely that the trees topple over from the weight of it all.

Although the mental vision of an ivy-covered cottage is a romantic one, in actuality Hedera helix aerial rootlets forcing into dry stacked stone, weakened mortar, and pushing under and through boards can be extensively destructive.
Where Hedera helix grows or is strewn it will guard the area against disasters and negative energies.
The seedpods of Hedysarum coronarium have a thorny surface.
The act of actually sneezing is what gave Helenium the supposed power of being able to rid oneself of evil spirits by sneezing them out.
Helianthella parryi plays a significant role in the production of honey.
In 1532 Pizarro reported that he had seen the Peruvian Incans worshiping giant Helianthus flowers, the design of which was also in gold on the robes of the Incan priestesses.
If growing Helianthus in the garden the gardener will have very good luck.
It is believed that if you put a Helianthus flower under the bed, you will dream about anything you need to know the truth about.
The face of the Helianthus flowers follow the sun.
Native American prairie Indians would put bowls of Helianthus seeds as a tribute on the graves of their dead loved ones.
An interesting love divination is that a girl will put three Helianthus seeds down her back and she will marry the first boy she happens to meet.
It is believed by some that a necklace of Helianthus seed, strung as beads, will protect the wearer against contracting smallpox.
It is believed by some that if you cut a Helianthus stalk at sunset while making a wish, the wish will come true before sunset the next day.

Regardless of its most common name, Helianthus tuberosus has no actual relationship to Jerusalem, although possibly with North American early settlers who carried roots with them to plant, who also considered that the New World would be their “New Jerusalem.”
The essential oil made from Helichrysum flowers is said to smell like a blend of burnt sugar and ham.
Although Helichrysum italicum is unrelated to the culinary spices used in curry, the fragrance of the plant smells intensely like it.
Heliconia is named in honor of Mount Helicon, in Greece, which is the mythological home of the Muses of Literature, Science, and Art.

If you have been the victim of a burglary and want to know who it was that stole from you, put Heliotropium flowers and leaves in a small white cotton or white silk pouch to place under your pillow. It is believed this will cause the identity of the thief to appear in a dream.

Although every part of the Helleborus is deadly poisonous, it was once believed that bringing a vase of Helleborus into a room full of dreadful negativity would push out the unpleasantness and replace it with tranquility.
Every part of the Helleborus foetidus is deadly poisonous, and for that reason it is too dangerous to use for any reason whatsoever.
Every part of the Helleborus niger is deadly poisonous and for that reason it is too dangerous to use for any reason whatsoever.
It is believed that Alexander the Great might have been treated for an illness with Helleborus niger, only to subsequently violently and grotesquely die from the plant’s dreadful poisoning.
Hemerocallis means “beauty for a day” in Greek, because the blossoms last for only one day.
Introduced to North America by European immigrants, Hemerocallis fulva originated in China and Korea.
Because the Hemerocallis fulva bulb can survive for weeks unplanted, they were carried across the sea and across North America by wagon trains, to now bloom wild along roadsides and railroad tracks.
Hemerocallis fulva flowers last for one day.
For a woman to secure a man’s love she should carry Hepatica at all times.

generalSymbolicMeanings: You are the queen of coquettes
colorMeaning: White: Despair not; God is everywhere.

folklore: The Hibiscus rosa-sinensis is called “Shoe Flower” because the petals can be used to shine shoes.

In the Pacific Islands, a red Hibiscus rosa-sinensis flower is worn by women as a sign of their interests. If worn behind the left ear, it signals that she desires a lover. If behind the right ear, she already has a lover. If a Hibiscus rosa-sinensis is worn behind both ears, it signals that she has a lover but would like another one.
In tropical countries, Hibiscus rosa-sinensis flowers are tucked into marital wreaths that are used as a marriage ceremony decoration.
Hibiscus trionum flowers are either white or yellow with a purple center.
Hieracium flowers are often confused with those of Taraxacum (Dandelion).
Found on or near coastal beaches, the Hippomane mancinella tree is one of the most poisonous trees in all the world. Every part of it is deadly poisonous.
Explorer Juan Ponce de Leon died a few days after being struck from an arrow poisoned with Hippomane mancinella sap by Calusa Indians camped near St. Petersburg, Florida.

The ancient Carib and Calusa Indians favored a manner of killing captives by simply tying the victim to the trunk of the Hippomane mancinella tree and letting the poisonous bark do the painful dirty deed.

A single drop of the milky sap of the Hippomane mancinella tree mixed with even one drop of rainwater or dew merely falling on the skin will cause blistering, so never take cover under it for any reason.
The smoke from a burning Hippomane mancinella tree can can cause blindness.

These trees are usually not marked as being deadly poisonous in most places, but you might see on the trunks marks such as a red “X,” a red band a few feet up from the ground, or an actual warning sign to indicate that this tree is extremely dangerous and to stay away from it.

Hordeum vulgare was one of the first grains that was actually domesticated in the Near East, dating back to approximately 1500–891 BCE. Evidence of Hordeum vulgare spontaneum (Wild Barley) dates back to approximately 8500 BCE.
The important significance of Hordeum vulgare is in religious rituals during ancient Middle East, Greek, and Egyptian times.

In medieval times, a type of divination using cakes made of Hordeum vulgare was often used to determine guilt or innocence. This is known as alphitomancy; if there was a group of suspected criminals to sort through, all of them were fed cakes or bread made of Hordeum vulgare. Supposedly, the person who got indigestion was the guilty party.
Scatter Hordeum vulgare on the ground near to your home to keep evil and negativity from approaching it.
Large, wide leaves on large, wide plants and lily-like flowers on tall stems makes low-light-tolerant, winter-hardy and easily grown Hosta an especially favored garden plant.
Frequently mistaken to be the five-petaled Forget-me-nots (Myosotis), Houstonia caerulea has four petals.
When grown in the house, Hoya offers protection.
Dry the Hoya flowers to wear as an amulet for power and protection.
Hoya carnosa is a climbing plant known for the dripping nectar and translucency of its star-shaped flowers.
Sleep on a pillow that has been stuffed with dried Humulus lupulus for improved rest.
The pleasingly fragrant Hyacinthoides non-scripta flower is a favored scent of many colognes and toiletry products in Great Britain.

colorMeaning: Blue: Consistency.
Pink: Harmless mischief; Play; Playful joy.
Purple: I’m sorry; Jealousy; Please forgive me; Regret; Sadness; Sorrow; Sorrowful.
Red: Harmless mischief; Play; Playful joy.
White: I’ll pray for you; Loveliness; Prayers for those in need; Unobtrusive loveliness.
Yellow: Jealousy.

folklore: Sniffing fresh Hyacinthus orientalis flowers will ease depression and grief.
Grown in a pot in the bedroom, Hyacinthus orientalis will prevent nightmares.
Empress Josephine of France grew and promoted the development of Hybrides remontants in her lush Malmaison gardens.
Hybrid Tea is the most common rose flower that florists use for creating corsages.
Carry or scatter Hydrangea bark around the home to break a hex.
Wild Hydrastis canadensis is an endangered species due to over-harvesting.

An enormous hedge of Hylocereus undatus that was planted in Honolulu in 1836 at the Punahou School by a woman by the name of Mrs. Bingham is supposedly the mother plant of nearly all of Hylocereus undatus in Hawaii, started from cuttings taken at the school for well over a century.

folklore: Malus domestica appears in the writings of many religions, most often as a forbidden fruit.

A concern about Malus domestica in religion, folk stories, and mythology is that the word “apple” was actually a generic term used to describe fruits and even nuts up until, at least, the seventeenth century. Therefore, it is not possible to know whether any particular “apple” was, in fact, a Malus domestica or something altogether different.

A simple divination using Malus domestica fruit involves cutting the fruit in half, then examining and counting what seeds are visible. If an odd number, the inquirer will remain unmarried in the near future. If the total is an even number, soon there will be marriage. If one of the seeds has been cut, the relationship will be volatile; if two seeds have been cut, widowhood is the foretelling.

Myosotis is also a symbol that signals shared secrets.
