Wear a cap of Myrica leaves when preparing a love charm.
Put a leaf of Myrica in an amulet you wear to draw love towards you.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Amulet to increase clarity of thought.

folklore: Carry the outer covering of Myristica fragrans to boost the intellect.
Carry a Myristica fragrans as a good luck charm.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Memory of the Garden of Eden
Scent of the Garden of Eden
Souvenir of the Garden of Eden
Symbol of the Garden of Eden

folklore: Myrtus communis is considered to be a sacred plant and is both the symbol and the scent of the Garden of Eden.
A sprig of Myrtus communis that was in Queen Victoria’s bridal bouquet was planted, and since then sprigs of that same plant have been included in royal bridal bouquets.
Carry Myrtus communis wood to preserve youthfulness.
Carry Myrtus communis to preserve love.
Grow Myrtus communis on each side of a house to promote peace and love within the home.
If a woman plants Myrtus communis in a window box, she will become lucky.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Energy that comes from being in love
Stay as sweet as you are
The sun shines when I’m with you

folklore: The Narcissus is the flower of the Underworld.
Animals do not eat the Narcissus flower because the sap contains sharp crystals.
Wear a Narcissus flower over your heart for good luck.
During medieval times in Europe it was thought that if a Narcissus drooped while it was being looked at, it was an omen of death.
Chicken farmers were superstitious and would not allow Narcissus into their homes, as they believed they were unlucky and would stop their hens from laying eggs or keep the eggs from hatching.
In Maine there is a superstition that if you point at a Narcissus with your index finger it will not bloom.
The Chinese believe that the Narcissus is lucky and will bring good luck for an entire year if forced to bloom during the Chinese New Year.
Fresh Narcissus flowers in a vase in the bedroom bodes well for fertility.

generalSymbolicMeanings: I desire a return of affection

folklore: This was the favorite flower of England’s Queen Anne, who loved the Narcissus jonquilla so dearly that it inspired her to create Kensington Palace Gardens (the first public botanical garden in England).
Narcissus poeticus is cultivated in the Netherlands for its essential oil, which is used in many perfume formulas.

Pure Nardostachys grandiflora is believed to be the plant that produced the perfume ointment that Mary, the sister of Lazarus, used to anoint Jesus’s feet six days before the Passover that preceded his crucifixion. Also, two days before that fateful death, an unnamed woman anointed Jesus’s head with the same type of perfume taken from an alabaster jar. The use of this exceptionally expensive perfume on Jesus, rather than being sold for 300 denarii (which would have been about a year’s wages), is what incited Judas Iscariot to his betrayal of Jesus, which led to Jesus’s arrest and subsequent crucifixion.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Enlightened one in a world of ignorant beings
Far from the one who is loved

folklore: The Nelumbo nucifera is highly regarded as a meaningful sacred plant in Egypt, India, Greece, and Japan as the mystical symbol of Life, Spirituality, and the Center of the Universe.

The viability of Nelumbo nucifera is quite incredible, and if conditions are ideal, the seeds that are viable can last a very long time. Currently, 1,500 years is the oldest germination of ancient Nelumbo nucifera seeds that were found in a dry Chinese lake bed.
Most deities of Asian religions are shown sitting upon a Nelumbo nucifera flower.
It is believed that anyone who breathes in the fragrance of a Nelumbo nucifera flower will benefit from the flower’s inherent protection.
Carry or wear any part of the Nelumbo nucifera plant to receive good luck and blessings.
Nepenthes actively lures prey to fall into a pitcher trap with color, sweet nectar, and often a very appealing fragrance.
The shapes of the Nepenthes “pitcher” evoke that of a condom or a champagne flute.
Insects fall into the pitcher to be absorbed by the plant as its only fertilizer.
The insects that are most frequently trapped in a Nepenthes pitcher are ants.
The largest species of Nepenthes have pitchers big enough to capture a curious rat.
Make a little pouch and fill it with Nepeta cataria, then give it to your cat to create a psychic bond.
Nepeta cataria supposedly attracts good spirits and good luck.

It is believed that if you are to hold Nepeta cataria in your hand until it becomes warm, then hold another person’s hand, that person will be your friend—but only for as long as you keep the Nepeta cataria that you used in the friendship spell in a safe place.
Nepeta cataria leaves are supposedly a favorite bookmark for magical books.
In Italy it is believed that bringing any part of the Nerium oleander into the home will surely bring disgrace, misfortune of all types, and also sickness.
Nicotiana rustica has long been regarded as a sacred plant by many Native American and South American Indian tribes.
South American Indians believe that smoking Nicotiana rustica makes it possible to speak with spirits.
Nicotiana rustica thrown into the water at the beginning of a water journey will appease the Water Spirit.
A piece of Nolina lindheimeriana in your pocket when gambling, job seeking, having difficulties at work, or requesting a pay raise will be a good luck charm.

As gallant as giving a Nosegay may be, it is the secret message delivered via each individual flower that provides the overall symbolism of the presentation of the tidy bouquet, since a little can, in fact, mean a lot.
Carry a nut of any kind to aid fertility.
Any nut that grows together with another to create a co-joined double nut is a very lucky charm.
Nymphaea alba is believed to be Great Britain’s largest flower.
The fragrance of Nymphaea alba is believed to have healing power.
Nymphaea alba can be used in any spell that is intended to reduce a sexual craving.
An ancient Egyptian myth tells of how the Sun God was born of a Nymphaeaceae blossom to light up the dark world.
Carry an Ocimum basilicum leaf in your pocket to bring you money.
An Ocimum basilicum leaf placed on a deceased Hindu is assurance that he or she will reach Paradise.
The ancient Greeks considered Ocimum basilicum to be a strong symbol of hate, misfortune, and poverty.

In the West Indies, Ocimum basilicum is placed around shops to attract customers. In other parts of the world, an Ocimum basilicum leaf is placed in cash registers and on the entry doors into shops to not only attract customers but also ensure continued financial success.
In Italy, Ocimum basilicum is a symbol for love and is widely used as a token of love.
Giving a sprig of Ocimum basilicum to a man means, “Be wary, for someone is plotting against you.”
According to Jewish legend, if you hold a sprig of Ocimum basilicum while fasting it will help you maintain your strength and resolve to proceed.
In Spain, a pot of Ocimum basilicum on a windowsill indicated that it was a house of ill repute.
The fragrance of Ocimum basilicum is said to provoke sympathy between two unsympathetic people.
Ocimum basilicum given as a gift will bring good luck into a new home.
A married couple can share one Ocimum basilicum leaf between them to rub over their hearts as a request that fidelity will bless their relationship.
In India, the Ocimum basilicum plant is considered to be sacred.
If you are seeking a job, sprinkle Ocimum basilicum at the front of the building you are entering for a job interview.
Carry Ocimum basilicum to feel safe moving positively forward, despite the threat of peril.
In the Pacific Northwest, Oemleria cerasiformis is a tenacious plant that is one of the first plants to grow and bloom to signal that spring is very near.
Indigenous people used Oenothera to mask their human scent when out hunting.
The gift of Oenothera flava would be well received by a much-loved partner.

variantMeaning: / Olea europaea branch: Peace.
/ Olea europaea leaf: Peace.

folklore: Scatter Olea europaea leaves in a room to create a vibration of peace.
In ancient times, Olea europaea oil was commonly used as fuel for lamps.
Olea europaea oil is used for healing and for blessings by anointing the recipient.
Brides in ancient Greece would traditionally wear Olea europaea crowns as their visible wish for fertility.
Hang an Olea europaea branch over the front door to fend away evil and prevent it from entering into the home.
Wear an Olea europaea leaf as a good luck charm.
Onobrychis is grown to incorporate into a healthy grazing animal’s diet.
Place a dried Ononis plant on the lintel of the doors of the home to protect the family from dangers of all kinds, including accidents, arguments, spells, and theft.

Nature’s attempt to ensure Ophrys apifera is adequately cross-pollinated provides the lip of the blossom to deceptively look like a female bee to a male, who approaches with a great but highly confused interest in mating. This effectively causes him to carry pollen to another flower, while Nature’s decoys continues to attract and then send him away disappointed, but toting pollen.
Ophrys bombyliflora is yet another of Nature’s clever tricks to promote cross-pollination of orchids, by using the mating instinct of the bumblebee to complete the task.

Ophrys insectifera presents one of the most sexually deceptive mimics of all the orchids, looking like the glossy wings of a flying bug, which lures male wasps to the flower to assist in cross-pollination.
Opuntia is native to the Americas, with samples being brought home by the Spanish, where it spread from Spain to all parts of the Mediterranean and North Africa.

The Aztecs grew Opuntia for the purpose of harvesting the cochineal scale it would be infested with, using it to produce red dye that was eventually worth more than gold, to ultimately be the same scarlet dye that was used to to color the fabric used for British soldiers’ “redcoat” uniforms.

colorMeaning: Pink: Pure affection.

folklore: It is believed that witches have used Orchis mascula roots in the creation of love potions.
It is believed that to attract love you should carry two Orchis mascula roots that have been sewn into a small pouch.
Two Orchis mascula roots is a good gift to a newlywed couple to ensure their future happiness.

Due to the immense danger of collecting the wild Origanum dictamnus on the rocky mountainsides and gorges of Crete, a great many deaths of Origanum dictamnus collectors have been reported over the centuries.
It is thought that if someone rubs Origanum majorana on themself before sleeping, they will dream of their future spouse.
Ancient Greeks believed Origanum majorana grew over the grave of a dead person who was happy.
Ancient Greeks and Romans would make crowns of Origanum majorana for bridal couples to wear as symbols of love, happiness, and honor.

powers: Reveals the mystical secrets for using Black Magic.
folklore: Origanum vulgare was virtually unknown in the United States until the end of World War II, when American soldiers who had been stationed in the Mediterranean made a point to bring seeds home with them.
Orobanche has proven to be a devastating parasitic weed that has wreacked havoc on crops, and even with aggressive measures taken, the seeds can remain viable in the soil for many decades.
Put Oryza sativa on the roof to protect a house against misfortune.
Put a container filled with Oryza sativa near the entry doors of the house to protect the home against evil.
It is believed by some that if you throw Oryza sativa up into the air it will bring rain.
Oryza sativa has long been tossed at a newly married couple to increase their fertility.
Osteospermum are native to sunny and warm South Africa.

Oxalis acetosella is sometimes referred to as a “Shamrock” because it has a three-leaved clover look, and so it is widely available and often kept or given as a potted-plant gift on St. Patrick’s Day.
Put a live plant or nosegay of fresh Oxalis acetosella in a sickroom to speed recuperation from wounds or illness.

powers: Charm against dangerous creatures, both real and imagined
Gives the gift of second sight
folklore: There is a legend that it was Eve who carried an Oxalis tetraphylla’s Four-Leaf Clover out of Eden to hold on to luck, hope, love, and faith.
If you want to avoid being inducted into the military, wear an Oxalis tetraphylla’s Four-Leaf Clover Lucky Leaf.
An Oxalis tetraphylla’s Four-Leaf Clover Lucky Leaf will also strengthen your psychic powers and enable you to detect the presence of other spirits if you are wearing it.
An Oxalis tetraphylla’s Four-Leaf Clover Lucky Leaf can lead you to money and other riches, most especially treasure and gold.
An Oxalis tetraphylla’s Four-Leaf Clover Lucky Leaf will offer protection against madness.
If you want to see fairies, put seven grains of Tricum (Wheat) atop an Oxalis tetraphylla’s Four-Leaf Clover Lucky Leaf.
One Oxalis tetraphylla’s Four-Leaf Clover Lucky Leaf in your shoe will help you meet a lover who is rich.
Pachira aquatica is often sold as a small tree or shrub houseplant that has a five-stem braided trunk, with each stem representing one of the five Chinese elements in Feng Shui.
Pachira aquatica is often decorated with red ribbons and other Chinese symbols of good fortune.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Omen of good fortune and a happy marriage

folklore: The earliest record of Paeonia officinalis was found in a Chinese tomb dating back to the first century.
Wear Paeonia officinalis to protect the body, mind, spirit, and soul.
A Paeonia officinalis flower within the home will fend off evil spirits.
Grow Paeonia officinalis in the garden to protect the home against storms and evil.
Wear a necklace that you have made from Paeonia officinalis root and coral beads to chase away an incubus.
Carry Paeonia officinalis as a cure for lunacy.

Even though a shift in the political climate of China replaced Paeonia suffruticosa with a plum tree as the national flower, it still holds a place of honored cultural significance, and is known as King of Flowers.
Paeonia suffruticosa has been depicted in Chinese art and literature more than any other flower in the country’s long history.
Panax will bring beauty, love, money, sexuality, and health to all who carry it.
An interesting way to make a wish is to carve your wish into a Panax root, then throw it into running water.

When it comes to hex removal, Panicum capillare does its best work at removing and eliminating a hex or a curse without blindly retaliating by sending it back to where it came from. The latter is a knee-jerk reaction and best avoided.

colorMeaning: Red: Pleasure.
White: Consolation; Dreams; Peace.

folklore: At one time Papaver orientale seedpods were gilded and worn to attract wealth.

An interesting divination that could be used to answer a perplexing question is to write that question on a piece of paper using blue ink, then fold it up and tuck it within a Papaver orientale seedpod. Put the pod under your pillow before sleeping to facilitate a dream that will answer the question.
The Romans believed that Papaver rhoeas could heal wounds inflicted by love.
Evidence of Papaver rhoeas flowers were found in 3,000-year-old Egyptian tombs.
The ancient Greeks believed that corn would not grow without the presence of Papaver rhoeas growing nearby.

After WWI the battle-torn holes in the fields in Flanders later filled up with Papaver rhoeas. A legend began that the flowers had come from the spilled blood of war, making the red Papaver rhoeas flower the official remembrance symbol of the war dead.

generalSymbolicMeanings: I cling to you both in sunshine and shade
I cling to you for better or worse.

folklore: Parthenocissus quinquefolia is a high-climbing vine that will grow anywhere except in dry sand.
Parthenocissus quinquefolia was once used to produce a poison for tipping arrows.

Passiflora caerulea is a powerful symbol of the suffering of Christ that has its own legend and was often used as an early visual teaching aid to explain the Christian Gospel before there were any printed materials.
A Passiflora caerulea flower in the home is believed to promote peacefulness by calming trouble and resolving problems.
Carry a Passiflora caerulea flower to attract friends.
Put a Passiflora caerulea leaf under the pillow to help you have restful sleep.
To spice up a marital love life, place a small piece of Pausinystalia yohimbe bark in a small pouch made from red silk and tuck it under the mattress of the marriage bed.

powers: Protects against the gazing eyes of strangers.
folklore: In Turkey, it is common that dried seed capsules from the Peganum harmala plant are hung in homes where they are used as vehicles for protection against the Evil Eye.

In the Middle East, ancient prayers and the dried seed capsules from the Peganum harmala plant are mixed with other ingredients and then put on hot charcoal until they burst with smoke, which then moves around the head of a person who believes they were gazed upon by strangers or directly exposed to the Evil Eye.
Pelargonium of all types are protective when grown or brought into the house as cut flowers and put into fresh water.
Pots of red Pelargonium crispum offer a lot of protection for the home and health.
The fruit/seedpod of all Pelargoniums are pointed and resemble a stork’s bill.
When rubbed, the leaves of Pelargonium crispum exude the fragrance of lemon.
Pelargonium fragrans variegatum has variegated leaves, and small white, purple, or pink flowers with a somewhat spicy fragrance that is reminiscent of nutmeg.
The essential oil distilled from the rose-scented leaves of Pelargonium graveolens are often used to supplement or entirely represent the fragrance of Rosa in personal and household products.
Pelargonium inquinans has a bright scarlet flower and is considered to be the botanical first plant discovered of what came to be the start of the Pelargonium genus, with many hybrids to follow.
Pelargonium odoratissum foliage is fragrantly reminiscent of fresh apples.

generalSymbolicMeanings: I engage you for the next dance
Your hand for the next dance
Your next dance is with me.

folklore: Pelargonium peltatum plants grow to abundantly fill and beautifully cascade from hanging baskets and window boxes.
Pelargonium quercifolium leaves resemble the shape of a Quercus Oak tree leaf.
The possible medicinal benefits of Pelargonium sidoides for use as a cold remedy is being scientifically researched.
Pelargonium zonale can be identified by the horshoe-shaped dark mark on its leaf.

Pure white Pentas, with its five-petaled star-like flowers, are the most rare of the species, making it especially suitable to be used as the floral ingredient in the casting of a “Fortune’s Blessing” spell.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Everything will be as it should be
What is to be will be.

folklore: There are well over 1,000 species of Peperomia, with several of them easily available as houseplants.

Although most Peperomia species grow on rotten wood as epiphytes, some of those that will thrive in potting soil are beloved common houseplants, such as the silvery streaked Peperomia argyeia (Watermelon Peperomia); large, smooth, and shiny Peperomia obtusifolia (Baby Rubber Plant); and the very dark, heart-shaped, wrinkled leaves of Peperomia caperata (Emerald Ripple Peperomia).
To grow a Persea americana plant in the home from the pit of a fruit that you have consumed will bring love into the home.
Carry a Persea americana pit to promote beauty.
A magic wand made from Persea americana is believed to be very powerful.
Persea borbonia wood is strong enough to be used to build a sturdy boat.
If you desire to conceive, carry or wear Persicaria bistorta.
If a poltergeist has become a pest, sprinkle an infusion of Persicaria bistorta all around to drive it away.
Petasites fragrans are either male or female.
In the British Isles, female Petasites fragrans plants are unknown.
Petroselinum crispum has been cultivated since 300 BCE.
Petroselinum crispum was valuable to witches because it was believed that it went to the Underworld nine times and back again before sprouting.
If one dreams about cutting Petroselinum crispum it is a bad omen for love, indicating that the dreamer will be double-crossed by a lover.
It is believed that to transplant Petroselinum crispum will bring bad luck for a year.
In medieval times, it was believed that to pluck a sprig of Petroselinum crispum while speaking an enemy’s name had the power to kill.
Ancient Romans and Greeks both placed Petroselinum crispum on dinner plates to both protect the food and keep away misfortune during mealtime.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Not as proud as you are

folklore: Newlyweds should grow a Petunia plant to magically assist in grounding them in their new cohabitation in a long-term home as a committed couple.
The bright scarlet, hummingbird-attracting flowers of the Phaseolus coccineus have inspired many gardeners to grow this vigorous vine more for its blooming beauty than for its beans.
Phaseolus coccineus is the oldest bean to have been cultivated, over 7,000 years ago, in what is now Mexico.
Particularly in the Far East, scattering Phaseolus vulgaris flowers is thought to appease demons.
English tradition associates Phaseolus vulgaris with death if one Phaseolus vulgaris in a pod is white instead of green.

A common European divination that is done with Phaseolus vulgaris is to hide three pods: one untouched (wealth), one half-peeled (comfort), and one fully peeled (poverty). Whichever Phaseolus vulgaris the inquirer found first, foretold the future.

Red Phaseolus vulgaris (Red Beans), which are indigenous to the Americas (each tribe having their own names and folk stories for the beans), were used by the Native American Indians as goods worthy of meaningful trade.
In the Middle Ages, a witch’s powers were nullified if one were to spit a mouthful of Phaseolus vulgaris at the witch’s face.
Put Phaseolus vulgaris bean in your mouth and then spit it out at an evil sorcerer.
Carry dried Phaseolus vulgaris beans as an amulet against evil magic and negativity.
Philadelphus is a beautiful shrub with fragrant white flowers that smell like a blend between orange blossom and jasmine.
Philadelphus received the name “Mock Orange” because to first look at the flowers, they do resemble citrus blossoms.
It is believed by some that if a piece of the Phoenix dactylifera frond is carried it will increase fertility.
A Phoenix dactylifera frond placed near the door of the home will keep evil from all sources from entering into it.

variantMeaning: / Phragmites australis single: Music.
/ Phragmites australis split: Folly; Indiscretion.
/ Phragmites australis bundle with panicles: Music.

folklore: Carry a sprig of Phytolacca to give you courage.

One specimen of one species of Picea, known as Picea abies, or “Norway Spruce,” has been found on Fulufjället Mountain, in Sweden, and is nicknamed “Old Tjikko.” Old Tjikko is 9,500 years old and considered the oldest-known living tree on Earth.
Because of its extreme popularity, the Pilea peperomioides plant, with its cute, flying-saucer flat leaves and satellite-arranged growth habit, has become premium priced and difficult to obtain.
Widely cultivated to try to meet the public’s demand, Pilea peperomioides will only grow in its natural environment in China, where it is very rare and endangered.
Pimenta dioica is often added to herbal mixtures to attract money or luck.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Spiritual restoration of one’s youthful exuberance and confidence.
variantMeaning: / Pimpinella anisum seed: Restoration of youth.

folklore: Place Pimpinella anisum seeds in the pillow to fend off unpleasant dreams.
Fresh Pimpinella anisum leaves will push away evil and are often used around a magic circle to keep evil spirits away from the magician within the circle.
Hang a sprig of fresh or dried Pimpinella anisum over the bed to restore your lost youth.

variantMeaning: / Pinus cone: Conviviality.

folklore: Cones from Pinus trees are carried to have vigor in old age.
Cones from Pinus trees are carried to increase fertility.
Because Pinus is an evergreen, in Japan it was once the custom to place a Pinus branch over the entrance door to the home to provide joy within the home.
Make a cross using Pinus needles and place it near the fireplace to prevent evil from entering the home via the chimney.
Pinus is the “Tree of Peace” to the Native American Iroquois Confederacy.
When burned, Pinus needles are believed to return a malicious spell back to the sender.
Pinus nigra trees live long lives, with some specimens over 500 years old.
In the past, due to its resinous sap, Pinus rigida was useful for producing pitch and short timbers for shipbuilding and railroad ties.
Native Americans often used Pinus rigida for canoe construction.
The ornamental Pinus sylvestris is the most common choice for a Christmas tree in the United States.
Carry a pouch with a bit of Piper nigrum within it to protect yourself against the Evil Eye.
Carry a pouch with a bit of Piper nigrum within it to protect yourself from having persistent envious thoughts.
Mix equal amounts of Piper nigrum with natural sea salt, then scatter around your property to rid it of evil and protect it from returning.
“Mastic” obtained from the resin of the Pistacia lentiscus tree is a vital ingredient in “myron,” the holy oil used in some Orthodox Church rituals.
To bring a zombie out of its trance and allow it to pass into death, give it Pistacia vera nuts that have been dyed red.
Around 700 BCE, Pistacia vera trees were supposedly included among the other plants showcased in ancient Babylon’s “Hanging Gardens.”
Bring fortune and profit to business by shelling Pisum sativum.

One interesting love divination is for an unmarried woman to find a Pisum sativum pod with exactly nine seeds within it. When this is done, if she hangs the pod over a door, the first single man that walks beneath it will be her future husband.

powers: Ingredient in the ancient Nine Herbs Charm
folklore: Not to be confused with the cooking “plantain,” which is a Musa, Plantago is a sidewalk crack and roadside weed with possible powers as used in magic charms.

After North America was first colonized, the Native American Indians began referring to Plantago major as “White Man’s Footprint” and “Englishman’s Foot” because to them, it seemed as if Plantago major would grow wherever white men went. This “phenomena” occurred because colonists would bring cereal crop seeds with them to the New World and Plantago major seeds were commonly mixed into the seed bags. So where settlers would plant cereal crops—which would be near to where they lived—Plantago major would grow and ultimately naturalize.
Hang Plantago major in the car to keep evil from entering into it.
Platanus trees were as sacred to ancient Egyptians and primitive nomadic tribes as the Oak was to ancient Druids.
Legend tells that Joseph and Mary rested under the shade of a Platanus tree when they were fleeing to Egypt from Bethlehem with baby Jesus.
The New York Stock Exchange terms of formation are called The Buttonwood Agreement because it was signed under a Platanus occidentalis tree located at 68 Wall Street, New York City, NY, back in 1792.
The name Plumbago may have been inspired by the lead-blue color of the flower, or the lead-colored stain the sap can create.
Asians have thought that the Plumeria provides shelter for demons and ghosts.

Malaysian folklore makes mention of the scent of Plumeria in association with the Pontianak (a type of vampire), which is supposedly the “undead” women who have died in childbirth and are seeking revenge.
Plumeria flowers are worn over an ear by the women in the Pacific Islands: over the right ear if available, and over the left if not.
Plumeria flowers are frequently used to make exquisite leis.
Plumeria is often associated with cemeteries and graves.
A ball of green Poaceae hanging in your front window or knots of Poaceae tied around your home will drive out evil and protect your home from evil entering back into it.
Carrying blades of Poaceae is helpful to your psychic powers.
To make a wish using Poaceae, rub some on a stone to create a green mark on it, make your wish upon that green spot, then either bury the stone or throw it into running water.
A piece of the dried fruit of Podophyllum peltatum in an amulet sachet will permit the carrier to work in secret.
A touch of Pogostemon cablin oil on money, handbags, and wallets is believed to increase prosperity.
A Polemonium caeruleum is used in the making of black dye.
Polemonium caeruleum flowers are often dried and added to potpourri blends.
Polygonatum root placed in all four corners of your home will protect it.
There is a legend that the scars on the roots of Polygonatum multiflorum were placed there by King Solomon to testify to its powerful virtues.
The age of the Polygonatum multiflorum plant can be determined by the number of scars along the root, as each year produces a new stem that dies at the end of every summer to leave a new scar.

One can tell True Solomon’s Seal (Polygonatum multiflorum) from False Solomon’s Seal (Maianthemum racemosum) by the fact that Polygonatum multiflorum has bell-shaped flowers dangling down along the stem. On the other hand, Maianthemum racemosum has flowering plumes at the end of the plant’s stems.
If you want to conceive, carry a Polygonum amulet.
If carried close to the breast, Polygonum is considered to be a good charm to help those suffering from frenzy.
Another power of Polygonum is that when a person touches it, Polygonum is believed to give that person the special powers offered by their astrological sun sign.
Polygonum is good for attracting money.
Polytrichum has been found to be able to grow in a wide variety of locations all over the world.
Polytrichum growing at a Roman fort archeological site in Newstead, England, has been dated back to 86 CE.
Carry Populus alba buds and leaves to attract money.
Place Populus alba buds and leaves on the bed and/or on the body to promote astral projection.
A tall tree with shiny heart-shaped leaves that can grow to be up to 166 feet (51 meters), due to the destruction of its natural habitat, Populus nigra is now endangered.

variantMeaning: / Populus tremula leaf: Lamentation; Sighing.

folklore: Carry a Populus tremula bud or leaf to attract money to you.
Place a Populus tremula bud or leaf to facilitate an attempt at astral projection.

variantMeaning: / Portulaca grandiflora bud: Confessions of love.

folklore: Prepare a sachet with Portulaca grandiflora within it and give it to a soldier to carry as protection when in battle.
Grow Portulaca grandiflora to protect the home and bring happiness to it.
There is a legend that the five points of the Potentilla leaves represent love, money, health, power, and wisdom. So, if carried about, these powers will be granted unto you.
If you happen to find a Potentilla leaf with seven points and put it under your pillow you will dream of your future lover.
Worn or carried Potentilla will give you the ability to ask favors with a positive outcome.
Wear a Potentilla leaf to court for a positive outcome.
To drive away evil, hang Potentilla erecta in the home.
To attract love, carry a sprig of Potentilla erecta.

To determine the difference between one wild strawberry and another, the false strawberry variety, Potentilla indica, has yellow flowers rather than the white or hybrid pink blossoms produced by true varieties.
Five oval-shaped petals overlay and alternate upon five-pointed, lance-shaped petals of the Potentilla rivalis flower.

Prenanthes purpurea will supposedly protect from snakes, but most importantly, it is supposed to be a protection from being caught up in a group of supposed “friends” who are as threatening and dangerous.
When Prenanthes purpurea is worn in a shoe it will supposedly protect the wearer from stepping into all varieties of problems caused by evil and trickery.

colorMeaning: Crimson: Confidence; Heart’s mystery; Pride of riches.
Lilac: Confidence.
Red: Merit; Unsolicited recognition; Unsupported merit.
Rose: Neglected genius.
Scarlet: Avarice.

folklore: Primula sinensis is a five-petaled flower that represents women throughout the feminine phases and passages of a woman’s life.
If you touch a fairy rock with a nosegay of Primula sinensis the wrong number of times it could initiate doom, though if done correctly it could open the door to fairyland and fairy gifts.
Primula sinensis is sacred to Druids.
Fairies love and protect Primula veris.
Primula veris flowers are considered fairy flowers in Ireland and Wales.

It is thought that touching a fairy rock with a Primula veris nosegay will open an invisible door into fairyland. However, if there are not the proper number of flowers in the nosegay there will be certain doom. The problem is that no one knows for sure what the proper number of flowers actually is!
It is also believed that Primula veris help children find hidden treasures, particularly fairy gold.
If you do not want visitors, put a sprig of Primula veris under or on the front porch.
Wear or carry Primula veris to preserve or restore your youth.
Grow red and blue Primula vulgaris in the garden to attract fairies to it and to protect it from all adversities.
Carry a Primula vulgaris flower to attract love.
Carry a Primula vulgaris flower to cure madness.
When water is scarce, the Prosopis tree, which can reach up to 50 feet (15 meters) high, will grow to be no taller than a shrub.
Protea cynaroides is one of the oldest flowers on Earth.
The Native American Dakota Indians have used Prunus americana tree sprouts to create prayer sticks.

variantMeaning: / Prunus armeniaca blossom: Distrust; Doubt; Timid love.

folklore: It is supposedly lucky for Prunus armeniaca to appear in a dream.

Prunus armeniaca has been cultivated in Armenia since prehistoric times, as indicated by seeds found at an Eneolithic-era (Eneolithic being the transitional period between the Neolithic period and the Bronze Age) excavation site at Garni, Armenia.
However, the Vavilov Center of Origin indicates that Prunus armeniaca was domesticated in the Chinese region; others believe that Prunus armeniaca was first cultivated in India around 3000 BCE.
Carry a Prunus armeniaca pit to attract love.

variantMeaning: / Prunus avium blossom: A good education; Ascetic beauty; Education; Feminine beauty; Gentle; Good education; Honor of graceful resignation; Insincerity; Kind; Peace; Spiritual beauty; Transience of life; Transience melancholy.

folklore: To find love, tie one strand of your hair to a Prunus avium tree.
Hang a Prunus domestica branch over the doors and windows of your home to protect it from evil entering in.

variantMeaning: / Prunus dulcis blossom: Hope; Watchfulness.

folklore: It is believed by some that Prunus dulcis nuts carried about in a pocket could lead you to treasures.
The nuts on a wild Prunus dulcis tree can be bitter and are not ever to be eaten as they are poisonous. Domesticated Prunus dulcis trees are not toxic.
It is believed that one can guarantee a successful business venture by climbing a Prunus dulcis tree.
Magic wands made of Prunus dulcis wood are highly valued.

variantMeaning: / Prunus laurocerasus flower: Perfidy.

folklore: The foliage of Prunus laurocerasus is commonly used in floristry.
During medieval times, Prunus padus bark was placed at the door to ward off plague.
In some parts of northern Scotland, Prunus padus wood is particularly avoided, as it is considered a wood from a “witch’s tree.”

generalSymbolicMeanings: Your qualities and charms are unequaled.
variantMeaning: / Prunus persica blossom: Captive; I am yours; I am your captive; Longevity; Long life; My heart is yours; Unequaled qualities.

folklore: In China, Prunus persica branches are used to drive off evil spirits.
Chinese children once wore a Prunus persica pit as a pendant to keep demons away from them.
It is believed that to carry a small piece of Prunus persica wood will lengthen your life and might even make you immortal.
In Japan, Prunus persica branches have been used as divining rods.
Prunus rainier will produce a golden-yellow fruit with a red blush.
Prunus rainier attracts birds to feed on the fruit of the tree.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Blessing to come after a challenge

folklore: Hang Prunus spinosa over doorways to ward off evil, calamity, and negative vibrations, and banish demons from the home.
A forked branch of Prunus spinosa will make a useful divining rod.
Prunus spinosa wood will make a good magical wand.

variantMeaning: / Pteridium aquilinum seed: Invisibility; Provides magical qualities.

folklore: It was once believed that a traveler would become disoriented, to the point of losing his direction, if he were to step upon Pteridium aquilinum.
To make it rain, burn some Pteridium aquilinum.
Place a frond of Pteridium aquilinum under the pillow to dream of the solution to a perplexing problem.
Add Pteridium aquilinum fronds to flower arrangements to increase protection.
In England it was once believed that hanging dried Pteridophyta in the house would protect everyone who dwelled there from thunder and lightning.
In England it was also once believed that cutting or burning Pteridophyta would bring on rain.
It was believed that the Pteridophyta seed would provide magic powers, such as invisibility, if carried in a pocket.
It was once believed that walking upon Pteridophyta would cause the traveler to become so confused that he would lose his way.
Pulmonaria leaves are sometimes used to represent diseased lungs in healing magic.

At one time, Pulsatilla sepals were used to color eggs for use in various spring festivals, as they will create an impermanent green stain. Since these spring events took place near Easter, the custom of coloring eggs was adopted by Christians celebrating Easter.
Growing red Pulsatilla flowers in the home garden will protect both the garden and the home.
It is believed that in the spring if you wrap the first Pulsatilla flowers that are seen in a red cloth, then wear or carry it with you, it will prevent disease.
Picking a Pulsatilla flower in Scotland was believed to initiate a thunderstorm.
Some believe that at night fairies sleep inside a closed Pulsatilla flower.

variantMeaning: / Punica granatum blossom: Binding; Divination; Elegance; Fertility; Incarceration; Mature elegance; Unreciprocated love magic; Wealth.
/ Punica granatum seeds: Love.

folklore: Carry a piece of Punica granatum husk to increase fertility.
Use a forked branch of Punica granatum as a divining rod to find hidden wealth.

A fun divination for a girl to try to find out how many children she might have is to throw a Punica granatum fruit onto the ground hard enough to break it open. However many seeds fall out of the fruit is the number of children she will someday have.
Hang a Punica granatum branch over a doorway to fend off evil.

variantMeaning: / Pyrus blossom: Comfort; Long life.

folklore: Pyrus wood is desirable for constructing a wand.

variantMeaning: / Quercus leaves: Bravery; Strength; Welcome.
/ Quercus sprig: Hospitality.
/ Quercus nut (acorn): Fruition of long hard labor; Good luck; Immortality; Life; Patience.

folklore: Quercus has been revered, even worshipped, since prehistoric times.
The Druids would only perform rituals under a Quercus tree.
A powerful protector against evil is a cross of Quercus wood made from equal lengths that is tied together in the center with red thread and hung in the house.
Carry a small piece of Quercus wood as protection from harm and as a good luck charm.
If you happen to catch a falling autumn Quercus leaf you will not have a cold for all of winter.
Carry a Quercus acorn for protection against aches and pains and illness.
Carry a Quercus acorn to promote youthfulness, and for longevity and even immortality.
Quercus is believed to increase fertility.
Quercus is believed to improve sexual powers.

variantMeaning: / Quercus alba leaves: Bravery; Strength; Welcome.
/ Quercus alba sprig: Hospitality.
/ Quercus alba nut (acorn): Fruition of long hard labor; Good luck; Immortality; Life; Patience.

folklore: Viscum album (Common Mistletoe) was most specifically searched for in the boughs of a Quercus alba tree, from which it would be ceremoniously cut down for ritual use. This is because the Viscum album—considered to be among the most magically imbued of all plants—is believed to be most sacred and most powerful when found in a Quercus alba tree.

In medieval times, manipulative beggars would deliberately rub the irritating Ranunculus acris sap on their skin to make open blistered sores to create sympathy in people who pass by who might then give them money out of pity for the beggars’ painful-appearing condition.
Known for a longer-lasting cut flower, Ranunculus asiaticus can look fresh in untreated plain water for up to a week.
Folk superstition has been that Ranunculus sardous is a plant that will produce “craziness” and madness.
Ranunculus sceleratus is commonly found growing near ponds or in wet ditches.
Carry a Raphanus sativus to offer protection against the Evil Eye.
There was a time in Germany when Raphanus sativus was carried to seek out the location of sorcerers.
To drive away all sorceries and enchantments from the home and occupants, place branches of Rhamnus cathartica near the windows and doors.
Carry or wear Rhamnus cathartica to undertake legal matters, including being in court.
Carry or wear Rhamnus cathartica to create good luck.
To help win a court case, before going to court sprinkle bits of Rhamnus purshiana around the home.
Wear Rhamnus purshiana to fend off hexes and evil.
At one time the rumor was that the Crown of Thorns wreath worn by Jesus Christ was shaped using green Rhamnus purshiana twigs.
Wear a piece of Rheum rhabarbarum around the neck on a string as protection against stomach pain.
Rhus leaves contain a high amount of tannin, which has been used since ancient times to tan leather.

variantMeaning: / Ribes nigrum branch: You please all.
/ Ribes rubrum branch: You please all.

folklore: Ribes uva-crispa were believed to be where fairies go to hide from danger.
Robinia flowers grow on the tree as large, pendulous, thick clusters of pink or white blossoms.
The roots of any plant, living or dead, once had or still retains natural power within it. Living roots left alone to continue growing undisturbed have the most power of all.

colorMeaning: Black: Beauty; Death; Farewell; Hatred; Impending death; Rebirth; Rejuvenation.
Blue: Attaining the impossible; Mystery.
Blush: If you love me you will discover it; If you love me you will find me out.
Bridal: Bliss; Happy love; Happiness.
Burgundy: Implicitly; Unconscious beauty.
Coral: Desire; Enthusiasm; Happiness; Passion.
Dark crimson: Mourning.
Dark Pink: Thank you.
Deep Red: Bashful; Mourning.
Dried white: Death before loss of innocence.
Green: Masculine energy.
Lavender: Enchantment; Love at first sight; Magic.
Light Pink: Admiration.
Orange: Desire; Enthusiasm; Fascination; Passion; Pride; Wonder.
Pale: Friendship.
Peach: Appreciation; Closing of the deal; Gratitude; Immortality; Let’s get together; Modesty; Sincerity.

Pink: Confidence; Desire; Elegance; Energy; Everlasting joy; Gentility; Grace; Grace and sweetness; Gratitude; Happiness; Indecision; Joy; Joy of life; Love; Passion; Perfect happiness; Perfection; Please believe me; Romance; Romantic love; Secret love; Sweetness; Thank you; Thankfulness; Trust; You’re so loved; Youth.
Red: Beauty; Congratulations; Courage; Desire; Healing; I love you; Job well done; Love; Passion; Protection; Respect; Well done.
Striped or Variegated: Immediate affection; Love at first sight; Warmth of heart.
Unique color: Uniquely beautiful.
Violet: Admiration; Deepest love; Enchantment; Love at first sight; Magic; Majestic; Opulent; Special.

White: Charm; Eternal love; Exorcism; Heavenly; Humility; I am worthy of you; Innocence; I would be single; Purity; Reverence; Secrecy; Silence; Virtue; Wistfulness; Worthiness; You’re heavenly; Youthfulness.
Yellow: Apology; Caring; Dying love; Friendship; Infidelity; Gladness; Jealousy; Joy; Love; Platonic love; Remember me; Welcome; Welcome back.
Pink and White together: I love you still and I always will.
Red and White together: Together; Unity.
Full bloom single stem any color: I love you; Simplicity.
Yellow single and eleven Red: Love and passion.
Orange and Yellow together: Passionate thoughts.
Red and Yellow together: Congratulations; Excitement; Happiness; Joy.
variantMeaning: / Rosa bud: see Rosa (Bud)
/ Rosa bouquet in full bloom: Gratitude.
/ Rosa crown: Beware of virtue; Reward of merit; Reward of virtue; Superior merit; Virtue.
/ Rosa full blown: You are beautiful.
/ Rosa garland: Beware of virtue; Reward of merit; Reward of virtue; Symbol of superior merit.
/ Rosa leaf: I never trouble; You may hope.
/ Rosa, one full-blown rose placed over two rosebuds: Secrecy.
/ Rosa thornless: Affection; Early attachment.
/ Rosa withered: Departed loveliness.
/ Rosa wreath: Beware of virtue; Reward of merit; Reward of virtue; Symbol of superior merit.

folklore: In 1840 there was a Rosa collection of over one thousand different cultivars, varieties, and species planted at a Victorian arboretum and non-denominational cemetary in England called Abney Park Cemetery, which operated from 1840 to around 1978 and is now a public park.

In Roman times a wild Rosa would be put on the door of a room where confidential matters were being discussed, hence, the term sub rosa, which meant “under the rose,” and now means “to keep a secret.”
Plant Rosa in the garden to attract fairies to it.
Scatter Rosa petals around the home to alleviate stress and household problems that have surfaced and are upsetting.

It is believed that a fairy is supposedly able to render itself invisible by eating a Rosa acicularis hip, then turning counterclockwise three times. To become visible again, the fairy would need to eat another Rosa acicularis hip, then turn clockwise three times.

colorMeaning: Pink: Pure; Pure and lovely; You are young and beautiful.
White: A heart ignorant of love; Girlhood; The heart that knows not love; Too young to love; Too young to marry.
Red: Romance.

folklore: Rose canina is a climbing wild rose.
Rose canina root was once believed to remedy the bite from a mad or rabid dog.
Rosa carolina is a prickly wild rose that is most commonly found freely growing in pasture land.
Rosa centifolia has a vibration higher than that of any other flower.

generalSymbolicMeanings: I want to smile like you
That smile I would aspire to
Thou art all that is lovely
You are all that is lovely.

folklore: Rosa foetida is a prolific-blooming, rambling briar with very pretty, vivid yellow flowers; its fragrance is peculiar.
Rosa gallica “Versicolor” flower petals are striped.
Rosa gymnocarpa is a spiny, five-petaled wild rose that is native to western North America.
A natural orange dye can be made from the fruit of Rosa majalis.

variantMeaning: / Rosa moschata Cluster: Charming.

folklore: Rosa moschata is believed to have originated in the Himalayas.

The rose that William Shakespeare mentioned in A Midsummer Night’s Dream is thought to be Rosa moschata, since it was the garden rose of his time. Rosa moschata is prickly, five-petaled, and very fragrant.
Rosa multiflora was first introduced to North America in 1866 with the intention of it becoming a hearty rootstock for the grafting of other roses.
In the 1930s the thorny Rosa multiflora was promoted to be grown as a flowering, living thicket fence to help with soil erosion.
Now the plant isnaturalized and invasive, and birds and animals continue to spread around the seeds of Rosa multiflora, which can be in the soil for up to twenty years and still germinate.
Rosa multiflora has been planted in some road medians to grow densely and perform as a crash barrier.
At one time Rosa rubiginosa was strictly a garden rose, until it escaped all boundaries to naturalize wildly along roadsides throughout Europe.

generalSymbolicMeanings: Beauty is not your only attraction.

folklore: Growing best in sandy seaside areas to stabilize the dunes and help protect against erosion, the thorny Rosa rugosa has gorgeous large flowers.
Rosa x damascena is an ancient sacred plant with a large, beautiful, fragrant flower that originated in Iran and is revered in the Middle East.
Rosa x damascena is the source of a pure essential oil that is used in some religious ceremonies.
To fragrance the house, Rosmarinus officinalis was commonly spread upon the floor at Christmastime during the Middle Ages.
It is believed that anyone who smells the aroma of Rosmarinus officinalis on Christmas Eve will have happiness throughout the coming year.
Since ancient times, when the practice was started in Greece, Rosmarinus officinalis has been used in both funeral and marriage rituals.
Students in ancient Greece would tuck sprigs of Rosmarinus officinalis behind an ear or in their hair to enhance their memories during academic exams.
Rosmarinus officinalis has been liberally used in wedding flowers, as the plant was thought to encourage the bridal couple to remember and stay true to their marriage vows.
It was believed that one would fall in love if touched on the finger by a sprig of Rosmarinus officinalis.
Rosmarinus officinalis was often included in specific magic spells.
A sprig of Rosmarinus officinalis under the pillow is supposed to be a remedy for nightmares.
Since back in the time of ancient Egypt, Rosmarinus officinalis was part of funeral rituals, also being used in the embalming process.
In medieval times it was thought that one must be righteous to grow Rosmarinus officinalis in their own garden.
In Australia, a sprig of Rosmarinus officinalis is worn on Anzac Day to remember the war dead of WWI.
Rosmarinus officinalis is supposedly grossly offensive to evil spirits.
In the Middle Ages a newlywed couple would plant a branch of Rosmarinus officinalis; if the branch did not thrive, it was a bad omen for the marriage and the family.
Rosmarinus officinalis is a common stuffing in the making of poppets used specifically to attract a lover.
A Rosmarinus officinalis plant on each side of an entry door to a home is said to repel witches.
Since ancient times, the root of the Rubia plant has been used to create dyes for natural fibers and leather.
Rubus wreaths mixed with Sorbus (Rowan) and Hedera helix (Ivy) can be used on a door front to keep away evil spirits.
In England it was considered bad luck to pick the Rubus fruit after October 11th.
Rubus was planted on graves to keep the dead from leaving their resting places as ghosts.

There was a time after a death had occurred that Rubus branches were placed at all the windows and exterior doors to prevent the spirit of the dead individual from reentering the home and taking up permanent resident there again in the form of a haunting.
Rubus berries were one of the earliest foods known to be eaten on Earth by a human being.

Rubus odoratus has a very pretty flower of such an attractive shade of purple on an extremely prickly brambling shrub that it would make a lovely hedge when one does not want an intruder breaching their boundary.
Although the plant is commonly called “Wild Petunia,” Ruellia is not related to the Petunia at all.
Supposedly, to help a woman conceive a child you should place a small amount of Rumex crispus seeds in a small cotton pouch and tie it to her left arm.
Rumohra adiantiformis is the most favored fern used by florists in arrangements that they design for almost any occasion, all over the world.
Thousands of Brazilians secure their income by selling Rumohra adiantiformis fronds that they harvest in the wild.
Catholic priests used to sprinkle holy water off the branch of Ruta graveolens.
A Ruta graveolens plant can live for hundreds of years.
There was once a time when Lithuanian brides would wear Ruta graveolens wreaths at their wedding.
In medieval times, Ruta graveolens was hung in the windows to keep any evil entity from coming into the house.
Also, in medieval times, Ruta graveolens was worn in a bunch at the waist to repel witches.
A Ruta graveolens leaf on the forehead is believed to relieve a headache.
Rub fresh Ruta graveolens leaves on the floor to revert any negative spells back to whoever cast them upon you.
It is believed that you can fend off werewolves by carrying a sprig of Ruta graveolens.
Saccharum was once considered a spice.
Saccharum is still used as a medicine in some folk remedies.
At some time around 800 BCE, Saccharum was first cultivated in New Guinea.
The white flowers of Sagina subulata are tiny, but the plant can bloom so abundantly that the flowers can nearly cover it over.
Grow Saintpaulia in the home to promote spirituality.
In ancient Rome, women were initiated into the role of motherhood by being flogged with Salix branches in a ritual that wished fertility upon them.
Salix is often the plant of choice to create living sculptures that are shaped to form figures and garden features such as domes and seating.
In Christian churches in northwestern Europe, Salix branches are often used as a substitute for palm in Palm Sunday ceremonies.
In China, Salix branches are often placed on gates and front doors to ward off evil spirits that wander about during the Qingming (Tomb Sweeping) festival.

Taoist witches will often use a carving made of Salix wood to communicate with spirits of the dead by sending the image into the netherworld where a spirit is to enter it, provide the information requested, and then give it to relatives upon its return.
In Old English folklore, a Salix tree can be malicious because it has the ability to uproot and move about stalking travelers.
Salix alba leaves attract love.
Salix alba is often used in wands that are particularly used for Moon Magic.
Salix alba in the home will offer protection against evil.
If you absolutely need to “knock on wood,” do it on a Salix alba tree.

´Smigus-dyngus (Dyngus Day) is a Slavic holiday following Lent on which single boys splash water on single girls, who slap them back on their heads flirtatiously with the fluffy catkin stems of the Salix alba—“Pussywillows.”
Salix repens is a low, creeping shrub found growing on heathland and sand dunes close to water.
For healing and/or prosperity, Salvia apiana is burned as an incense, worn as an amulet, and/or used as an ingredient in a sachet.
Burning Salvia apiana will purify an area by removing negativity and spiritual impurities, and banishing evil, thus consecrating the area and providing protection.
Salvia cacaliifolia has a deep, bright blue flower.
The ancient Romans believed that Salvia officinalis was powerful enough to create immortal life.
It was once believed that Salvia officinalis would thrive only in gardens of homes controlled by a woman.
Salvia officinalis was often planted in cemeteries because it was believed that it would easily thrive on neglect and therefore live and grow forever.

Since ancient times, Salvia officinalis has been used to ward off evil and more. It was a major ingredient in a medieval medicinal/magical concoction called “Four Thieves Vinegar,” which was supposedly used to ward off the plague.

If you write a wish on a Salvia officinalis leaf, put it under your pillow, and then sleep upon it for three consecutive days, and if you dream of it coming true, it will come true. If you do not dream of that wish coming true, you must take that leaf and bury it immediately so that it brings you no harm.
Salvia sclarea is sometimes considered to be “a woman’s herb” because of the calming and centering effect the fragrance can have on the emotions.

variantMeaning: / Sambucus flower: Compassion; Humility; Kindness; Zeal.

folklore: Sambucus nigra is associated with witches.
When the dead were once buried, branches of Sambucus nigra were planted with the body to protect them from evil spirits.
Stone Age arrowheads were shaped to look like elder leaves.
A cross made of Sambucus nigra wood and attached to the stables is supposed to keep evil away from the animals.
Cradles were not to be made of Sambucus nigra wood because the baby would either fall out of it, not be able to sleep, or be pinched by fairies.
The English believe that burning logs of Sambucus nigra will bring the devil into the house.
Before pruning a Sambucus nigra tree, one must ask the tree’s permission, then spit three times before making the first cut.
Sambucus nigra leaves gathered on the last day of April can be attached to the doors and windows to keep witches from entering the home.
Sambucus nigra trees or Sambucus nigra hedges grown near a home’s entrance will keep evil from entering.
An amulet of a piece of Sambucus nigra wood on which the sun has never shone is tied between two knots and then worn around the neck as protection against evil.
Sanguinaria worn in an amulet will attract love, and repel evil spells and all types of negativity.
Place Sanguinaria near windows and doors to protect the home.
Beads made of Santalum album are protective and facilitate spiritual awareness whenever they are worn.
Santalum album is a threatened species in the wild.
Santalum album is one of the most expensive woods in the world.
When you enter into a temple it will most likely smell like Santalum album.
The Pennsylvania Amish used dried Santolina in their food closet to keep away weevils.
Carry a piece of Sassafras in the purse or wallet to attract money to it.
Carry or wear a sprig of Satureja to strengthen your mind.
Cultivated Saxifraga hypnoides will grow into a lush, green, moss-like carpet.
A Saxifraga stolonifera plant is most attractive when planted in a hanging pot or basket, so the long threadlike runners, each tipped with a tiny baby plantlet, can freely drape over the sides.
The tiny Saxifraga stolonifera blossoms have three smaller pink petals on one side of the stamen with two much longer white petals across from them.

Saxifraga x urbium grew quickly at the bombed locations following the London Blitz of WWII to become a symbol to Londoners of resistance, fortitude, and the refusal to submit to being bombed into submission by an enemy.
Scabiosa atropurpurea is an appropriate flower to offer to someone who is mourning the death of their life partner.
Scabiosa atropurpurea is a suitable flower to include in a funeral wreath.
The Scaevola aemula flower looks like it has been cut in half, leaving five petals on one side to resemble the five fingers of a hand.

The meaning of the Scaevola aemula flower was supposedly inspired by a Roman soldier who was given its name (which he passed on to all of his descendants) after deliberately crippling his left hand in fire to prove his bravery.
Schefflera is one of the trees most often potted to be brought inside to be used as an impressive houseplant.

Mexican traditional healers have used Schinus branches in healing by brushing the branch over the sick individual with the expectation that the branch will absorb the sickness. Then the branch is burned to destroy the disease.
A strange thing about Schlumbergera russelliana is that when it buds, to avoid the bud dropping off do not turn the plant.
Scilla has been used in Greek magic since the fifth century.
A method of attracting money is to put Scilla in a jar, then add silver coins to it.
To break a hex, wear or carry Scilla.
Wear a piece of Scrophularia in an amulet around the neck for protection against the Evil Eye.
When a woman wears or carries a sprig of Scutellaria she protects her husband against the enticing charms of another woman.
Scutellaria is useful as a restorative in recovering from a magical attack and any demanding spiritual working.
Sempervivum was once commonly grown on rooftops to ward off fire, lightning strikes, and witches.
If worn fresh and replaced every third day, Sempervivum is believed to bring love.
Wearing a Senecio cambrensis amulet is believed to prevent toothaches.
The ancient Greeks used Senecio cambrenis as an amulet of choice against spells and charms used against the wearer.
During the dark days of persecution of witches, it was claimed that the witches rode out at midnight, not upon broomsticks, but on stalks of Senecio cambrenis.
Every month, put fresh Sesamum indicum seeds in a jar in the house and leave the lid off to draw money to it.
Sida fallax is a flower often used in the construction of Hawaiian leis.
In ancient Hawaii, Sida fallax flowers and leaves were reserved for royalty.
A diviner of the Xhosa tribe of South Africa will gather wild Silene for use during a full moon divining ritual.
Silene coronaria, as the Latin word coronaria implies, is a flower that was useful in the fashioning of garlands.
The pretty little dark pink to red Silene dioica flowers can be found throughout most of the British Isles.
On the Isle of Man, picking Silene dioica is in violation of a local taboo, believing that it is very bad luck to do so, will vex the fairies, and bring down fairy wrath upon them all.
Silene noctiflora will open in the evening to exude a fragrance that attracts the night-flying moths that will feed on the nectar and cross-pollinate the plant.
Amazingly, like a magnet, the living Silphium laciniatum flower’s head and leaves align north and south.
Legend tells that God created the Silphium laciniatum to aid travelers.
There is an old Anglo-Saxon belief that if a man were to wear Silybum marianum around his neck any snakes anywhere within his presence would become enraged and begin to fight.
Put a small piece of Solanum dulcamara in a little pouch and tie it to somewhere on the body to remove evil.
It is believed by some that a large fruit of the Solanum lycopersicum placed on the mantle in a home will bring prosperity.
The fruit of the Solanum lycopersicum placed at any entrance to the home will repel evil from entering.
Solanum lycopersicum growing in the garden will scare away evil.

variantMeaning: / Solanum tuberosum blossom: Benevolence.

folklore: It is believed by some that if you carry a very small Solanum tuberosum in your pocket it will protect you against gout, warts, rheumatism, cure a toothache, cure a cold if you have one, and protect you from contracting one if you carry the tuber all winter long.

The leaves of most of the many different cultivated Solenostemon scutellarioides plants have very colorfully distinctive pattern variations, with one or more different shades of maroon, purple, cream, pinks, yellow, white, bronze, and several different greens.
Solidago gets the primary blame for hay fever.
Witches frequently used Solidago in their potions.
